{{pp-pc1}} {{Short description|American painter}} {{Infobox artist | name = Chuck Close | image = Chuck Close.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Chuck Close in 2009 | birth_name = Charles Thomas Close | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1940|07|05}} | birth_place = [[Monroe, Washington]] | nationality = American | field = [[Photorealistic]] painter, photographer | training = [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]], [[University of Washington]], 1962; [[Master of Fine Arts|M.F.A.]], [[Yale University]] }}
'''Charles Thomas "Chuck" Close''' (born July 5, 1940) is an American painter, artist and photographer who achieved fame as a [[photorealist]], through his massive-scale portraits. Close often paints abstract portraits of himself and others, which hang in collections internationally. Close also creates photo portraits using a very large format camera. Even though a catastrophic spinal artery collapse in 1988 left him severely paralyzed, he has continued to paint and produce work that remains sought after by museums and collectors.
==Early life and education== Chuck Close was born in [[Monroe, Washington]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Chuck Close profile|publisher=Art in the Allen Center|url=http://www.cs.washington.edu/building/art/ChuckClose|accessdate=2007-08-15|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070907154813/http://www.cs.washington.edu/building/art/ChuckClose/|archivedate=2007-09-07|df=}}</ref> His father, Leslie Durward Close, died when Chuck was eleven years old. His mother's name was Mildred Wagner Close.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/interviews/oral-history-interview-chuck-close-13141|title=Oral history interview with Chuck Close|accessdate=December 9, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114113706/http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/interviews/oral-history-interview-chuck-close-13141|archivedate=January 14, 2015|df=}}</ref> Close suffered, as a child, from a neuromuscular condition that made it difficult to lift his feet and a bout with [[nephritis]] that kept him out of school for most of sixth grade. Even when in school, he did poorly due to his [[dyslexia]], which wasn't diagnosed at the time.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hylton|first1=Wil S.|authorlink=Wil S. Hylton|title=The Mysterious Metamorphosis of Chuck Close|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/17/magazine/the-mysterious-metamorphosis-of-chuck-close.html|accessdate=July 14, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=July 13, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160713212317/http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/17/magazine/the-mysterious-metamorphosis-of-chuck-close.html|archivedate=July 13, 2016|df=}}</ref>
Most of his early works are very large portraits based on photographs, using [[Photorealism]] or [[Hyperrealism (painting)|Hyperrealism]], of family and friends, often other artists. He suffers from [[prosopagnosia]] (face blindness), and has suggested that this condition is what first inspired him to do portraits.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mosaicartnow.com/2010/07/prosopagnosia-portraitist-chuck-close|title=Mosaic Art NOW: Prosopagnosia: Portraitist Chuck Close|publisher=mosaicartnow.com|accessdate=August 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170821091200/http://www.mosaicartnow.com/2010/07/prosopagnosia-portraitist-chuck-close/|archivedate=August 21, 2017|df=}}</ref>
In an interview with [[Phong Bui]] in ''[[The Brooklyn Rail]]'', Close describes an early encounter with a [[Jackson Pollock]] painting at the [[Seattle Art Museum]]: "I went to the Seattle Art Museum with my mother for the first time when I was 14.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/chuck-close-9251491#early-life|title=Chuck Close|author=|date=|website=Biography|accessdate=1 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323000921/https://www.biography.com/people/chuck-close-9251491#early-life|archivedate=23 March 2018|df=}}</ref> I saw this Jackson Pollock drip painting with aluminum paint, tar, gravel and all that stuff. I was absolutely outraged, disturbed. It was so far removed from what I thought art was. However, within 2 or 3 days, I was dripping paint all over my old paintings. In a way I've been chasing that experience ever since."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bui|first=Phong|title=In Conversation: Chuck Close with Phong Bui|journal=The Brooklyn Rail|date=June 2008|url=http://brooklynrail.org/2008/06/art/chuck-close-with-phong-bui|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20120406132818/http://brooklynrail.org/2008/06/art/chuck-close-with-phong-bui|archivedate=2012-04-06|df=}}</ref>
Close attended [[Everett Community College]] in 1958–60.<ref name="Chuck Close">[http://www.crownpoint.com/artists/100/biographical-summary Chuck Close] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023003134/http://www.crownpoint.com/artists/100/biographical-summary |date=2012-10-23 }} Crown Point Press, San Francisco.</ref> Local notable eccentric, author, activist and journalist [[John Patric]] was an early anti-establishment intellectual influence on him, and a role model for the iconoclastic and theatric artist's persona Close learned to project in subsequent years.<ref name=close>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_98hkDCFoJ4C&pg=PT38&dq=%22John+Patric%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lWD-VOTNE9beoASQt4K4Aw&ved=0CDkQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22John%20Patric%22&f=false|title=Chuck Close: Life}}</ref>
In 1962, Close received his B.A. from the [[University of Washington]] in [[Seattle]]. In 1961, he won a coveted scholarship to the Yale Summer School of Music and Art,<ref name="Chuck Close"/> and the following year entered the graduate degree program at [[Yale University]], where he received his [[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]] in 1964. Among Close's classmates at Yale were [[Brice Marden]], [[Vija Celmins]], [[Janet Fish]], [[Richard Serra]], [[Nancy Graves]], [[Jennifer Bartlett]], [[Robert Mangold]], and [[Sylvia Plimack Mangold]].<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
After Yale, he studied at the [[Academy of Fine Arts Vienna]] on a [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright]] grant.<ref name="guggenheim.org">[http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/show-full/bio/?artist_name=Chuck%20Close&page=1&f=Name&cr=1 Chuck Close] [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]], New York.</ref> When he returned to the US, he worked as an art teacher at the [[University of Massachusetts Amherst|University of Massachusetts]]. Close came to New York City in 1967 and established himself in [[SoHo]].<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
==Work==
===Style=== [[Image:Chuck Close 1.jpg|thumb|350px|''Mark'' (1978 - 1979), acrylic on canvas. [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[New York, New York]]. Detail at right of eye. This is a photorealistic painting representative of Close's earlier style, in contrast to his later "pictorial syntax" using "many small marks of paint".<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Close to the Edge |last=Newhall |first=Edith |magazine=[[New York Magazine]] |date=April 15, 1991 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aukCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA38&dq=chuck+close+mark+1978&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwii-IXygN7TAhVN1GMKHeVMDVMQ6AEITDAH#v=onepage&q&f=false |pages=40–41}}.</ref> Laboriously constructed from a series of cyan, magenta, and yellow airbrushed layers that imitated [[CMYK color model|CMYK color printing]],<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sYAGCAAAQBAJ&pg=PT148&dq=chuck+close+mark+1978&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi04urr_93TAhVW6WMKHUJZDMUQ6AEIIzAA#v=onepage&q=these%20coloured%20portraits&f=false |title=Face Politics |page=unnumbered, n. 130 |last=Edkins |first=Jenny |publisher=[[Routledge]] |date=2015 }}.</ref> it took Close fourteen months to complete. Compare the picture's integrity close up with the later work below, executed through a different technique.]] [[Image:Chuck Close 2.jpg|thumb|350px|''Lucas'' (1986 - 1987), oil and graphite on canvas. [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[New York, New York]]. Detail at right of eye. Representative of his "later, more colorful and painterly style", "the elements of the picture are seen as separate abstract markings" when viewed close-up, while simultaneously maintaining the illusion of a realistic portrait at a distance.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/484760 |title=Chuck Close: Lucas I |publisher=[[The Metropolitan Museum of Art]] |accessdate=May 7, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170724082821/http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/484760 |archivedate=July 24, 2017 |df= }}.</ref> The pencil grid and thin undercoat of blue is visible beneath the splotchy "pixels." The painting's subject is fellow artist [[Lucas Samaras]].]] Throughout his career, Chuck Close has expanded his contribution to portraiture through the mastery of such varied drawing and painting techniques as ink, graphite, pastel, watercolor, conté crayon, finger painting, and stamp-pad ink on paper; printmaking techniques, such as Mezzotint, etching, woodcuts, linocuts, and silkscreens; as well as handmade paper collage, Polaroid photographs, Daguerreotypes, and Jacquard tapestries.<ref>[http://www.blumandpoe.com/exhibitions/chuck-close#press Chuck Close, October 29 – December 22, 2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113024806/http://www.blumandpoe.com/exhibitions/chuck-close |date=January 13, 2012 }} [[Blum & Poe]], Los Angeles.</ref> His early airbrush techniques inspired the development of the [[ink jet printer]].<ref name="Lyle Rexer 2000">Lyle Rexer (March 12, 2000), [https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/12/arts/art-architecture-chuck-close-rediscovers-the-art-in-an-old-method.html Chuck Close Rediscovers the Art in an Old Method] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307110324/http://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/12/arts/art-architecture-chuck-close-rediscovers-the-art-in-an-old-method.html |date=2016-03-07 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref>
Close had been known for his skillful brushwork as a graduate student at Yale University. There, he emulated [[Willem de Kooning]] and seemed "destined to become a third-generation [[abstract expressionist]], although with a dash of Pop iconoclasm".<ref name="nytimes.com"/> After a period in which he experimented with [[Figurative art|figurative]] constructions, Close began a series of paintings derived from black-and-white photographs of a female nude, which he copied onto canvas and painted in color.<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/chuck-close-920 Chuck Close] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120805032544/http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/chuck-close-920 |date=2012-08-05 }} [[Tate Modern]], London.</ref> As he explained in a 2009 interview with Cleveland, Ohio's ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' newspaper, he made a choice in 1967 to make art hard for himself and force a personal artistic breakthrough by abandoning the paintbrush. "I threw away my tools", Close said. "I chose to do things I had no facility with. The choice not to do something is in a funny way more positive than the choice to do something. If you impose a limit to not do something you've done before, it will push you to where you've never gone before."<ref>Norman, M. [http://www.cleveland.com/arts/index.ssf/2009/09/contemporary_art_legend_chuck.html Contemporary Art Legend Chuck Close Talks About Painting] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100604015731/http://www.cleveland.com/arts/index.ssf/2009/09/contemporary_art_legend_chuck.html |date=2010-06-04 }}, The Plain Dealer, September 1, 2009</ref> One photo of [[Philip Glass]] was included in his resulting black-and-white series in 1969, redone with watercolors in 1977, again redone with stamp pad and fingerprints in 1978, and also done as gray handmade paper in 1982.
Working from a gridded photograph, he builds his images by applying one careful stroke after another in multi-colors or grayscale. He works methodically, starting his loose but regular grid from the left hand corner of the canvas.<ref>[http://whitecube.com/exhibitions/chuck_close_photographs/ Chuck Close: Photographs, 23 July – 4 September 1999] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123213841/http://whitecube.com/exhibitions/chuck_close_photographs/ |date=23 January 2015 }} [[White Cube]], London.</ref> His works are generally larger than life and highly focused.<ref>[http://www.paceprints.com/artist/172 Chuck Close] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318050514/http://www.paceprints.com/artist/172 |date=2012-03-18 }} Pace Prints, New York.</ref> "One demonstration of the way photography became assimilated into the art world is the success of photorealist painting in the late 1960s and early 1970s. It is also called super-realism or hyper-realism and painters like [[Richard Estes]], [[Denis Peterson]], [[Audrey Flack]], and Chuck Close often worked from photographic stills to create paintings that appeared to be photographs. The everyday nature of the subject matter of the paintings likewise worked to secure the painting as a realist object."<ref>Thompson, Graham: American Culture in the 1980s (Twentieth Century American Culture) Edinburgh University Press, 2007</ref>
Close suffers from [[prosopagnosia]], also known as face blindness, in which he is unable to recognize faces. By painting portraits, he is better able to recognize and remember faces.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/entertainment/july-dec10/close_07-06.html For Chuck Close, an Evolving Journey Through the Faces of Others] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140121223236/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/entertainment/july-dec10/close_07-06.html |date=2014-01-21 }} [[PBS Newshour]] July 6, 2010</ref> On the subject, Close has said, "I was not conscious of making a decision to paint portraits because I have difficulty recognizing faces. That occurred to me twenty years after the fact when I looked at why I was still painting portraits, why that still had urgency for me. I began to realize that it has sustained me for so long because I have difficulty in recognizing faces."<ref>Yuskavage, Lisa. [http://bombsite.com/issues/52/articles/1868 "Chuck Close"] {{webarchive|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20110818034248/http://bombsite.com/issues/52/articles/1868 |date=2011-08-18 }}, "[[BOMB Magazine]]", Summer, 1995. Retrieved July 25, 2011.</ref>
Although his later paintings differ in method from his earlier canvases, the preliminary process remains the same. To create his grid work copies of photos, Close puts a grid on the photo and on the canvas and copies cell by cell. Typically, each square within the grid is filled with roughly executed regions of color (usually consisting of painted rings on a contrasting background) which give the cell a perceived 'average' hue which makes sense from a distance. His first tools for this included an airbrush, rags, razor blade, and an eraser mounted on a power drill. His first picture with this method was ''Big Self Portrait'', a black and white enlargement of his face to a {{convert|107.5|x|83.5|in|cm}} canvas, made in over four months in 1968, and acquired by the [[Walker Art Center]] in 1969. He made seven more black and white portraits during this period. He has been quoted as saying that he used such diluted paint in the airbrush that all eight of the paintings were made with a single tube of [[Mars Black (pigment)|Mars Black]] acrylic.
His later work has branched into non-rectangular grids, [[topographic map]] style regions of similar colors, [[CMYK]] color grid work, and using larger grids to make the cell by cell nature of his work obvious even in small reproductions. The ''Big Self Portrait'' is so finely done that even a full page reproduction in an art book is still indistinguishable from a regular photograph.
==="The Event"=== On December 7, 1988, Close felt a strange pain in his chest. That day he was at a ceremony honoring local artists in New York City and was waiting to be called to the podium to present an award. Close delivered his speech and then made his way across the street to [[Beth Israel Medical Center]] where he suffered a seizure which left him paralyzed from the neck down. The cause was diagnosed as a spinal artery collapse.<ref>O'Hagan, Sean [https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2005/oct/09/art Head Master] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161204075534/https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2005/oct/09/art |date=2016-12-04 }}, The Observer, October 9, 2005</ref> He had also suffered from neuromuscular problems as a child.<ref>Christian Viveros-Faune (July 18, 2012), [http://www.villagevoice.com/2012-07-18/art/a-visit-with-art-world-hero-chuck-close/ A Visit With Art-World Hero Chuck Close] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120901100912/http://www.villagevoice.com/2012-07-18/art/a-visit-with-art-world-hero-chuck-close/ |date=2012-09-01 }} ''[[Village Voice]]''.</ref> Close called that day "The Event". For months, Close was in rehab strengthening his muscles with physical therapy; he soon had slight movement in his arms and could walk, yet only for a few steps. He has relied on a wheelchair ever since. Close spoke candidly about the effect disability had on his life and work in the book ''[[Chronicles of Courage: Very Special Artists]]'' written by [[Jean Kennedy Smith]] and [[George Plimpton]] and published by [[Random House]].<ref name="JKS book">[http://www.jfklibrary.org/JFK/The-Kennedy-Family/Jean-Kennedy-Smith.aspx Chronicles of Courage: Very Special Artists] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110409165454/http://www.jfklibrary.org/JFK/The-Kennedy-Family/Jean-Kennedy-Smith.aspx |date=2011-04-09 }}.</ref>
However, Close continued to paint with a brush strapped onto his wrist, creating large portraits in low-resolution grid squares created by an assistant. Viewed from afar, these squares appear as a single, unified image which attempt photo-reality, albeit in pixelated form. Although the paralysis restricted his ability to paint as meticulously as before, Close had, in a sense, placed artificial restrictions upon his hyperrealist approach well before the injury. That is, he adopted materials and techniques that did not lend themselves well to achieving a photorealistic effect. Small bits of irregular paper or inked fingerprints were used as media to achieve astoundingly realistic and interesting results. Close proved able to create his desired effects even with the most difficult of materials to control. Close has made a practice, over recent years, of representing artists who are similarly invested in portraiture, like [[Cecily Brown]], [[Kiki Smith]], [[Cindy Sherman]], and [[Zhang Huan]].<ref>Martha Schwendener (September 27, 2013), [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/29/nyregion/a-review-of-chuck-close-recent-works-at-guild-hall-museum.html Works in Conversation With Photography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171019163944/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/29/nyregion/a-review-of-chuck-close-recent-works-at-guild-hall-museum.html |date=2017-10-19 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref>
===Prints=== Close has been a printmaker throughout his career, with most of his prints published by [[Pace Gallery|Pace Editions]], New York.<ref name="Chuck Close"/> He made his first serious foray into print making in 1972, when he moved himself and family to San Francisco to work on a [[mezzotint]] at Crown Point Press for a three-month residency. To accommodate him, Crown Point found the largest copper plate it could (36 inches wide) and purchased a new press, allowing Close to make a work that was 3 feet by 4 feet. In 1986 he went to Kyoto to work with Tadashi Toda, a highly respected woodblock printer.<ref>Scarlet Cheng (January 21, 2007), [http://articles.latimes.com/2007/jan/21/entertainment/ca-close21 Proof is in the printing] {{webarchive|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20120820074051/http://articles.latimes.com/2007/jan/21/entertainment/ca-close21 |date=2012-08-20 }} ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.</ref>
In 1995, curator [[Colin Westerbeck]] used a grant from the Lannan Foundation to bring Close together with Grant Romer, director of conservation at the [[George Eastman House]].<ref name="Lyle Rexer 2000"/> Ever since, the artist has also continued to explore difficult photographic processes such as [[daguerreotype]] in collaboration with [[Jerry Spagnoli]] and sophisticated modular/cell-based forms such as [[tapestry]]. Close's photogravure portrait of artist [[Robert Rauschenberg]], "Robert" (1998), appeared in a 2009 exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington, New York, featuring prints from Universal Limited Art Editions.<ref>Genocchio, B: [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/08/nyregion/long-island/08artsli.html?_r=1 Prints That Say Bold and Eclectic] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010211639/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/08/nyregion/long-island/08artsli.html?_r=1 |date=2017-10-10 }}, ''[[The New York Times]]'', March 4, 2009</ref> In the daguerreotype photographs, the background defines the limit of the image plane as well as the outline of the subject, with the inky pitch-black setting off the light, reflective quality of the subject's face.<ref name="whitecube.com">[http://whitecube.com/artists/chuck_close/ Chuck Close] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904041458/http://whitecube.com/artists/chuck_close/ |date=2012-09-04 }} [[White Cube]], London.</ref>
In a 2014 interview with Terrie Sultan, Close said: "I've had two great collaborators in the God knows how many years I've been making prints. One was the late Joe Wilfer, who was called the 'prince of pulp' … and now I'm working with [[Donald Farnsworth|Don Farnsworth]] in Oakland at…[[Magnolia Editions]]: I do the watercolor prints with him, I do the tapestries with him. These are the most important collaborations of my life as an artist."<ref>{{cite web|last=Close|first=Chuck|title="Chuck Close & Terrie Sultan" Interview at Strand Bookstore, May 1, 2014|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tedC8_s90rE|author2=Terrie Sultan|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150202224549/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tedC8_s90rE|archivedate=February 2, 2015|df=}}</ref>
Since 2012, Magnolia Editions has published an ongoing series of archival [[watercolor]] prints by Close which use the artist's grid format and the precision afforded by contemporary digital printers to layer water-based pigment on Hahnemuhle rag paper<ref name="weinreich" /> such that the native behavior of watercolor is manifested in each print: "The edges of each [[pixel]] bleed with cyan, magenta, and yellow, creating a kind of three-dimensional fog effect behind the intended color swatches."<ref>[http://hamptonsarthub.com/2013/09/09/art-review-sumptuous-portraits-by-chuck-close-at-guild-hall-museum/ "Art Review: Sumptuous Portraits by Chuck Close at Guild Hall Museum".] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005211114/http://hamptonsarthub.com/2013/09/09/art-review-sumptuous-portraits-by-chuck-close-at-guild-hall-museum/ |date=2013-10-05 }} Hamptons Art Hub. Retrieved on 2013-10-08.</ref> The watercolor prints are created using more than 10,000 of Close's hand-painted marks which were scanned into a computer and then digitally rearranged and layered by the artist using his signature grid.<ref>[http://www.pacegallery.com/newyork/exhibitions/12548/chuck-close "Press Release: Chuck Close."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214173146/http://www.pacegallery.com/newyork/exhibitions/12548/chuck-close |date=2013-12-14 }} Pace Gallery. Retrieved 2013-10-08.</ref> These works have been called Close's first major foray into digital imagery:<ref>[http://www.fastcodesign.com/1671037/after-decades-of-pixel-painting-chuck-close-goes-truly-digital "After Decades of Pixel Painting, Chuck Close Goes Truly Digital."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130924184425/http://www.fastcodesign.com/1671037/after-decades-of-pixel-painting-chuck-close-goes-truly-digital |date=2013-09-24 }} Co.Design. Retrieved on 2013-10-08.</ref> according to Close, "It's amazing how precise a computer can be working with light and color and water."<ref>[http://www.lipulse.com/art-music/article/interface#sthash.jOjVkO31.dpuf "Interface: American Master Chuck Close."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327213710/http://www.lipulse.com/art-music/article/interface |date=2014-03-27 }} Kelly, Brian: Long Island Pulse Magazine. September 20, 2013. Retrieved on 2013-10-08.</ref> A New York Times review notes that the "exaggerated breakdown of the image, particularly when viewed at close range," that characterizes Close's work "is also apparent in... [watercolor print] portraits of the artists [[Cecily Brown]], [[Kiki Smith]], [[Cindy Sherman]], [[Kara Walker]] and [[Zhang Huan]]."<ref name="Schwendener">[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/29/nyregion/a-review-of-chuck-close-recent-works-at-guild-hall-museum.html?emc=eta1&_r=1& "A Review of 'Chuck Close – Recent Works,' at Guild Hall Museum."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180501124345/https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/29/nyregion/a-review-of-chuck-close-recent-works-at-guild-hall-museum.html?emc=eta1&_r=1& |date=2018-05-01 }} Schwendener, Martha: The New York Times, September 27, 2013. Retrieved on 2013-10-08.</ref>
===Tapestries=== Close's wall-size tapestry portraits, in which each image is composed of thousands of combinations of woven colored thread, depict subjects including [[Kate Moss]], [[Cindy Sherman]], [[Lorna Simpson]], [[Lucas Samaras]], [[Philip Glass]], [[Lou Reed]], [[Roy Lichtenstein]], and Close himself.<ref name="Schwendener" /> They are produced in collaboration with Donald Farnsworth.<ref>{{cite book | last = Finch | first = Christopher | title = Chuck Close: Work | year = 2007 | publisher = Prestel | isbn = 978-3-7913-3676-3 | pages = 286}}</ref> Although many are translated from black-and-white daguerreotypes, all of the tapestries use multiple colors of thread. No printing is involved in their creation; colors and values appear to the viewer based on combinations of more than 17,800 colored warp (vertical) and weft (horizontal) threads, in an echo of Close's typical grid format.<ref>[http://www.chron.com/entertainment/article/Artist-s-portrait-of-Kate-Moss-dazzles-1784474.php "Artist's Portrait of Kate Moss Dazzles."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150124025337/http://www.chron.com/entertainment/article/Artist-s-portrait-of-Kate-Moss-dazzles-1784474.php |date=2015-01-24 }} Britt, Douglas: Houston Chronicle, October 29, 2008. Retrieved 2013-10-08.</ref><ref>[http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/reviews/lawrence/lawrence10-17-07.asp "Capital Roundup."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126181736/http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/reviews/lawrence/lawrence10-17-07.asp |date=2009-01-26 }} artnet Magazine. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> Close's tapestry series began with a 2003 black-and-white portrait of Philip Glass. In August 2013 he debuted two color self-portraits at Guild Hall Museum in East Hampton, New York.<ref name="weinreich">[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/regina-weinreich/chuck-close-up-close-at-g_b_3737126.html "Chuck Close: Up Close at Guild Hall."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130811234944/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/regina-weinreich/chuck-close-up-close-at-g_b_3737126.html |date=2013-08-11 }} Weinreich, Regina: the Huffington Post. August 10, 2013. Retrieved 2013-10-08.</ref> Reviewing this exhibition, Marion Weiss writes: "Close's Jacquard tapestries are not obviously fragmented, but are created by repeating multicolor warp and weft threads that are optically blended. Thus, portraits of Lou Reed and Roy Lichtenstein, for example, seem 'whole.' It's only when we get closer that we see the individual threads, which are woven together."<ref>[http://danspapers.com/2013/08/chuck-close-is-visual-magic-at-guild-hall-in-east-hampton/ "Chuck Close is Visual Magic at Guild Hall in East Hampton."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130906232010/http://danspapers.com/2013/08/chuck-close-is-visual-magic-at-guild-hall-in-east-hampton/ |date=2013-09-06 }} Weiss, Marion Wolberg: Dan's Papers. August 30, 2013. Retrieved on 2013-10-08.</ref>
===Commissions=== In 2010, Close was commissioned by [[MTA Arts & Design]] to create twelve large mosaics, totaling more than {{convert|2000|ft2|m2}}, for the [[86th Street (Second Avenue Subway)|86th Street]] subway station on the [[New York City Subway]]'s [[Second Avenue Subway|Second Avenue Line]] in [[Manhattan]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Ben Yakas |url=http://gothamist.com/2014/01/22/heres_what_the_second_avenue_subway.php |title=Here's What The Second Avenue Subway Will Look Like When It's Filled With Art |publisher=Gothamist |date=2014-01-22 |accessdate=2014-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330041727/http://gothamist.com/2014/01/22/heres_what_the_second_avenue_subway.php |archivedate=2014-03-30 |df= }}</ref><ref>Noreen Malone (May 14, 2012), [http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2012/05/chuck-close-art-for-second-avenue-subway.html Chuck Close Will Make the Second Avenue Subway Pretty] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120518181728/http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2012/05/chuck-close-art-for-second-avenue-subway.html |date=2012-05-18 }}. ''[[New York Magazine]]''.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/19/arts/design/second-avenue-subway-art.html|title=Art Underground: A First Look at the Second Avenue Subway|last=Kennedy|first=Randy|date=2016-12-19|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2017-01-13|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109203314/http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/19/arts/design/second-avenue-subway-art.html|archivedate=2017-01-09|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://hyperallergic.com/348918/a-underground-tour-through-the-art-of-second-avenue-subway/|title=From Chuck Close to Sarah Sze, a Ride Through the Art of the Second Avenue Subway|date=2017-01-03|newspaper=Hyperallergic|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-13|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116175759/http://hyperallergic.com/348918/a-underground-tour-through-the-art-of-second-avenue-subway/|archivedate=2017-01-16|df=}}</ref>
''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair's]]'' 20th Annual Hollywood edition in March 2014 featured a portfolio of 20 Polaroid portraits of movie stars shot by Close, including [[Robert De Niro]], [[Scarlett Johansson]], [[Helen Mirren]], [[Julia Roberts]] and [[Oprah Winfrey]]. Close requested that his subjects be ready to be photographed without makeup or hair-styling and used a large-format 20x24" Polaroid camera for the close-ups.<ref>[http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2014/03/chuck-close-hollywood-portfolio The 2014 Vanity Fair Hollywood Portfolio] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140314121633/http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2014/03/chuck-close-hollywood-portfolio |date=2014-03-14 }} ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair's]]'', March 2014.</ref>
A fragment of Close's portrait of singer-songwriter [[Paul Simon]] was used as the cover art for his 2016 album ''[[Stranger to Stranger (Paul Simon album)|Stranger to Stranger]]''. The right eye appears on the cover; the entire portrait is in the liner notes.
Close donated an original print of his "Self Portrait" in 2002 to the [[Sno-Isle Libraries|public library]] in Monroe, Washington, his hometown.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lewis |first=Betsy |date=August 20, 2016 |title=Exhibit prompts story of how Monroe Library got its Close 'Self Portrait' |url=http://www.heraldnet.com/opinion/exhibit-prompts-story-of-how-monroe-library-got-its-close-self-portrait/ |work=The Everett Herald |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211235432/http://www.heraldnet.com/opinion/exhibit-prompts-story-of-how-monroe-library-got-its-close-self-portrait/ |archivedate=February 11, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
==Exhibitions== Close's first solo exhibition, held in 1967 at the [[University Museum of Contemporary Art|University of Massachusetts Art Gallery]], Amherst, featured paintings, painted reliefs, and drawings based on photographs of record covers and magazine illustrations. The exhibition captured the attention of the university administration which promptly closed it, citing the male nudity as obscene. The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) and the [[American Association of University Professors]] (AAUP) came to the defense of Close and a landmark court case ensued. A Massachusetts Supreme Court Justice decided in favor of the artist against the university. When the university appealed Close chose not to return to Boston, and ultimately the decision was overturned by an appeals court.<ref name="pacegallery.com">[http://www.pacegallery.com/newyork/exhibitions/12653/nudes-1967-2014 Chuck Close: Nudes 1967–2014, February 28 – March 29, 2014] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140312015116/http://www.pacegallery.com/newyork/exhibitions/12653/nudes-1967-2014 |date=March 12, 2014 }} [[Pace Gallery]], New York.</ref> (Close was later awarded an Honorary Doctorate of the Arts by the University of Massachusetts in 1995.)<ref name="pacegallery.com"/>
Close credits the [[Walker Art Center]] and its then-director Martin Friedman for launching his career with the purchase of ''Big Self-Portrait'' (1967–1968)<ref>[http://collections.walkerart.org/item/object/77 Chuck Close, ''Big Self-Portrait'' (1967–1968)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120817121605/http://collections.walkerart.org/item/object/77 |date=2012-08-17 }} [[Walker Art Center]], Minneapolis.</ref> in 1969, the first painting he sold<ref>Mary Abbe (June 5, 2012), [http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/blogs/157352585.html Former Walker director Martin Friedman toasted in New York] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718014606/http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/blogs/157352585.html |date=2012-07-18 }} ''[[Star Tribune]]''.</ref> His first one-man show in New York was in 1970 at [[Bykert Gallery]]. His first print was the focus of a "Projects" exhibition at the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in 1972. In 1979 his work was included in the [[Whitney Biennial]] and the following year his portraits were the subject of an exhibition at the Walker Art Center. His work has since been the subject of more than 150 solo exhibitions including a number of major museum retrospectives.<ref name="guggenheim.org"/> After Close abruptly canceled a major show of his work scheduled for 1997 at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]],<ref>Carol Vogel (January 31, 1996), [https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/31/arts/chuck-close-to-get-a-show-at-the-modern.html Chuck Close to Get a Show at the Modern] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305160430/http://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/31/arts/chuck-close-to-get-a-show-at-the-modern.html |date=2016-03-05 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> the Museum of Modern Art announced that it would present a major midcareer retrospective of the artist's work in 1998 (curated by [[Kirk Varnedoe]] and later traveling to the [[Hayward Gallery]], London, and other galleries in 1999).<ref>[[Phoebe Hoban]] (March 1, 1998), [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/01/style/the-night-artists-in-paint-and-in-person.html Artists, In Paint and In Person] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305192436/http://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/01/style/the-night-artists-in-paint-and-in-person.html |date=2016-03-05 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref><ref>[[Michael Kimmelman]] (February 27, 1998), [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/27/arts/art-review-playful-portraits-conveying-enigmatic-messages.html Playful Portraits Conveying Enigmatic Messages] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307020446/http://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/27/arts/art-review-playful-portraits-conveying-enigmatic-messages.html |date=2016-03-07 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> In 2003 the [[Blaffer Gallery]] at the [[University of Houston]] presented a survey of his prints, which travelled to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, the following year.<ref name="guggenheim.org"/> His most recent retrospective – "Chuck Close Paintings: 1968 / 2006", at the [[Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofia]] in Madrid in 2007 – travelled to the Ludwig Forum für Internationale Kunst in Aachen, Germany, and the [[State Hermitage Museum]] in St. Petersburg, Russia. He has also participated in almost 800 group exhibitions,<ref name="aspeninstitute.org">[http://www.aspeninstitute.org/news/2009/05/27/chuck-close-named-2009-harman-eisner-artist-residence Chuck Close Named 2009 Harman Eisner Artist In Residence] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222000846/http://www.aspeninstitute.org/news/2009/05/27/chuck-close-named-2009-harman-eisner-artist-residence |date=2014-02-22 }} [[Aspen Institute]].</ref> including [[documenta]]s V (1972) and VI (1977), the [[Venice Biennale]] (1993, 1995, 2003), and the [[Carnegie International]] (1995).<ref name="whitecube.com"/>
In 2013, Close's work was featured in an exhibit in White Cube Bermondsey, London. "Process and Collaboration" displayed not only a number of finished prints and paintings but included plates, woodblocks, and mylar stencils which were used to produce a number of prints.<ref>{{cite web |year=2013 |title=Chuck Close Prints: Process and Collaboration |url=http://whitecube.com/exhibitions/chuck_close_prints_process_and_collaboration_bermondsey_2013/ |publisher=White Cube |accessdate=10 February 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170502101050/http://whitecube.com/exhibitions/chuck_close_prints_process_and_collaboration_bermondsey_2013/ |archivedate=2 May 2017 |df= }}</ref>
In December 2014 his work was exhibited in [[Australia]] at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Sydney|Museum of Contemporary Art]] in [[Sydney]], which he visited.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-11-28/new-york-artist-chuck-close-on-his-work-with/5927152 New York artist Chuck Close on painting 'face blind'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141203061122/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-11-28/new-york-artist-chuck-close-on-his-work-with/5927152 |date=2014-12-03 }}, Sasha Koloff, [[ABC News Online]], 3 December 2014</ref>
In 2016, Close's work was the subject of a retrospective at the [[Schack Art Center]] in [[Everett, Washington]], where he attended high school and community college.<ref>{{cite news |last=Fiege |first=Gale |date=May 28, 2016 |title=Artist Chuck Close returns to old friends and a show at The Schack |url=http://www.heraldnet.com/news/artist-chuck-close-returns-to-old-friends-and-a-show-at-the-schack/ |work=[[The Everett Herald]] |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211235407/http://www.heraldnet.com/news/artist-chuck-close-returns-to-old-friends-and-a-show-at-the-schack/ |archivedate=February 11, 2017 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Upchurch |first=Michael |date=May 17, 2016 |title=Chuck Close, who revolutionized portraiture, has major retrospective in Everett |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/visual-arts/face-value-chuck-close-who-revolutionized-portraiture-has-major-retrospective-in-everett/ |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |accessdate=February 10, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211161808/http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/visual-arts/face-value-chuck-close-who-revolutionized-portraiture-has-major-retrospective-in-everett/ |archivedate=February 11, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
==Collections== Close's work is in the collections of most of the great international museums of contemporary art, including the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]] in Paris, the [[Tate Modern]] in London, and the [[Walker Art Center]] in Minneapolis who published ''Chuck Close: Self-Portraits 1967–2005'' coauthored with curators [[Siri Engberg]] and [[Madeleine Grynsztejn]].<ref name="Chuck Close"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Siri Engberg|url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/s/siri-engberg?store=allproducts&keyword=siri+engberg|publisher=Barnes & Noble|accessdate=May 3, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116162407/http://www.barnesandnoble.com/s/siri-engberg?store=allproducts&keyword=siri+engberg|archivedate=January 16, 2014|df=}}</ref>
==Recognition== The recipient of the [[National Medal of Arts]] from President [[Bill Clinton]] in 2000,<ref>[http://www.nea.gov/honors/medals/medalists_year.html#00 Lifetime Honors – National Medal of Arts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100304001626/http://www.nea.gov/honors/medals/medalists_year.html |date=March 4, 2010 }}</ref> the [[New York State Governor's Art Award]], and the Skowhegan Arts Medal, among many others, Close has received over 20 honorary degrees including one from [[Yale University]], his alma mater.<ref name="aspeninstitute.org"/> In 1990, he was elected into the [[National Academy of Design]] as an Associate Academician, and became a full Academician in 1992. New York Mayor [[Michael R. Bloomberg]] appointed the artist to the Cultural Affairs Advisory Commission, a body mandated by the City Charter to advise the mayor and the cultural affairs commissioner.<ref>[[Jennifer Steinhauer]] (February 25, 2003), [https://www.nytimes.com/2003/02/25/nyregion/metro-briefing-new-york-manhattan-mayor-names-cultural-advisers.html New York: Manhattan: Mayor Names Cultural Advisers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819021840/http://www.nytimes.com/2003/02/25/nyregion/metro-briefing-new-york-manhattan-mayor-names-cultural-advisers.html |date=2017-08-19 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> Close painted President Clinton in 2006 and photographed President [[Barack Obama]] in 2012.<ref name="pacegallery.com"/> In 2010 he was appointed by Obama to the [[President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities]].<ref name="guggenheim.org"/> He resigned from the President's Committee in August 2017, co-signing a letter of resignation that said in reference to President [[Donald Trump]], "Ignoring your hateful rhetoric would have made us complicit in your words and actions."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/i/TODAY/z_Creative/PCAHResignation.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-08-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819020132/http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/i/TODAY/z_Creative/PCAHResignation.pdf |archivedate=2017-08-19 |df= }}</ref>
In 2005, composer [[Philip Glass]] wrote a musical portrait of Close. The composition, a 15-minute piece for solo piano, was the idea of Bruce Levingston, a concert pianist, who commissioned it through the Premiere Commission and who performed the piece at a recital at [[Alice Tully Hall]] that year.<ref>Charles McGrath (April 22, 2005), [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/22/arts/music/22glas.html A Portraitist Whose Canvas Is a Piano] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150510171139/http://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/22/arts/music/22glas.html |date=2015-05-10 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref>
==Art market== Close has been represented by The [[Pace Gallery]] (in [[New York City]]) since 1977, and by [[White Cube]] (in [[London]]) since 1999.<ref>[http://thepacegallery.com/Artists/ViewArtist.aspx?artist=ChuckClose&type=Artist&guid=34336f1b-1e84-4cb5-a2b6-a500a3c68813 The Pace Gallery website]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Already in 1999, Close's ''Cindy II'' (1988), a portrait of the photographer [[Cindy Sherman]] sold for $1.2 million, against a high estimate of $800,000.<ref>Carol Vogel (November 17, 1999), [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/17/nyregion/auction-sets-records-for-18-contemporary-artists.html Auction Sets Records for 18 Contemporary Artists] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819133808/http://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/17/nyregion/auction-sets-records-for-18-contemporary-artists.html |date=2016-08-19 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> In 2005, ''John'' (1971–72) was sold at [[Sotheby's]] to the [[Eli Broad|Broad Art Foundation]] for $4.8 million.<ref>Carly Berwick (May 11, 2005), [http://www.nysun.com/arts/contemporary-art-market-returns-to-sanity/13644/ Contemporary Art Market Returns to Sanity] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309001934/http://www.nysun.com/arts/contemporary-art-market-returns-to-sanity/13644/ |date=2013-03-09 }} ''[[New York Sun]]''.</ref>
==Personal life== Close lives and works in [[Bridgehampton, New York]] and [[Long Beach, NY]] (both on the south shore of [[Long Island]])<ref name="nytimes.com">Helen A. Harrison (February 22, 2004), [https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/22/nyregion/following-the-light-and-making-faces.html Following the Light, and Making Faces] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222162744/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/22/nyregion/following-the-light-and-making-faces.html |date=2017-12-22 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> and [[New York City]]'s [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]].<ref name="Wall Street Journal">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304315004579383132591584424|title=An Artist Finds the Perfect Red|date=6 March 2014|publisher=|via=Wall Street Journal|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170411054733/https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304315004579383132591584424|archivedate=11 April 2017|df=}}</ref> He has two daughters with Leslie Rose.<ref>Wendy Goodman (May 28, 2007), [http://nymag.com/homedesign/greatrooms/32375/ Buy, Rip, Repeat] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415080936/http://nymag.com/homedesign/greatrooms/32375/ |date=2012-04-15 }}. ''[[New York Magazine]]''.</ref> They divorced in 2011. Close married artist [[Sienna Shields]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hylton|first1=Wil|title=The Mysterious Metamorphosis of Chuck Close|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/17/magazine/the-mysterious-metamorphosis-of-chuck-close.html|work=The New York Times|date=July 13, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160713212317/http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/17/magazine/the-mysterious-metamorphosis-of-chuck-close.html|archivedate=July 13, 2016|df=}}</ref> They later divorced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/painter-chuck-close-subway-art-divorce-longevity-article-1.3506879|title=SEE IT: Chuck Close gives first video tour of his subway art|author=|date=|website=nydailynews.com|accessdate=1 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180315134002/http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/painter-chuck-close-subway-art-divorce-longevity-article-1.3506879|archivedate=15 March 2018|df=}}</ref>
==Sexual harassment allegations== On December 20, 2017, two women accused Close of sexual misconduct, claiming he made vulgar comments to them after inviting them to his studio to pose for him.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hyperallergic.com/418222/chuck-close-accused-sexual-misconduct/|title=Renowned Artist Chuck Close Under Fire for Alleged Sexual Misconduct [UPDATED]|publisher=Hyperallergic|accessdate=December 29, 2017|date=December 20, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230115517/https://hyperallergic.com/418222/chuck-close-accused-sexual-misconduct/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=}}</ref> In response to the accusations, Close issued an apology to ''[[The New York Times]]'', saying "If I embarrassed anyone or made them feel uncomfortable, I am truly sorry, I didn't mean to."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/20/arts/design/chuck-close-sexual-harassment.html|title=Chuck Close Apologizes After Accusations of Sexual Harassment|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 20, 2017|accessdate=December 29, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228125650/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/20/arts/design/chuck-close-sexual-harassment.html|archivedate=December 28, 2017|df=}}</ref> The [[National Gallery of Art]] cancelled a Chuck Close exhibition, planned to open May 2018, because of the accusations of sexual misconduct that have engulfed the artist in controversy.<ref>Colin Moynihan And Robin Pogrebin. [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/26/arts/design/national-gallery-of-art-cancels-chuck-close-thomas-roma-sexual-misconduct.html "The National Gallery of Art Cancels a Chuck Close Show After Misconduct Accusations"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180127182525/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/26/arts/design/national-gallery-of-art-cancels-chuck-close-thomas-roma-sexual-misconduct.html |date=2018-01-27 }}, ''[[The New York Times]]'', January 26, 2018. Retrieved on January 27, 2018.</ref>
==Fundraising and community service==
In 2007 Close was honored by the [[New York Stem Cell Foundation]] and donated artwork for an exclusive online auction.<ref>{{cite web|title=NYSCF Exclusive Online Art Auction Now Closed|url=http://www.nyscf.org/events/past-events/item/713-nyscf-launches-exclusive-online-art-auction-now-chuck-close-christo-and-roy-lichtenstein|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123212212/http://www.nyscf.org/events/past-events/item/713-nyscf-launches-exclusive-online-art-auction-now-chuck-close-christo-and-roy-lichtenstein|archivedate=2015-01-23|df=}}</ref>
In September 2012 [[Magnolia Editions]] published two tapestry editions and three print editions by Close depicting President [[Barack Obama]]. The first tapestry was unveiled at the [[Mint Museum]] in [[North Carolina]] in honor of the [[Democratic National Convention]]. These tapestries and prints were sold as a fundraiser to support the Obama Victory Fund. A number of the works were signed by both Close and Obama. Close has previously sold work at auction to raise funds for the campaigns of [[Hillary Clinton]] and [[Al Gore]].<ref>[http://blogs.artinfo.com/artintheair/2012/09/10/you-can-buy-chuck-closes-tapestry-portrait-of-barack-obama-for-100000/ "You Can Buy Chuck Close's Tapestry Portrait of Barack Obama for $100,000"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213044816/http://blogs.artinfo.com/artintheair/2012/09/10/you-can-buy-chuck-closes-tapestry-portrait-of-barack-obama-for-100000/ |date=2013-12-13 }} artinfo.com. Retrieved on 2013-02-13.</ref><ref>[http://www.newyorker.com/talk/2012/09/17/120917ta_talk_tomkins "Chuck Close, President Obama, and an Art Sale"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212101323/http://www.newyorker.com/talk/2012/09/17/120917ta_talk_tomkins |date=2013-12-12 }} newyorker.com. Retrieved on 2013-02-13.</ref>
In October 2013, Close donated a watercolor print of Genevieve Bahrenburg and a watercolor print self-portrait to ARTWALK NY, a cause that benefits the [[Coalition for the Homeless]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Bahrenburg|first=Genevieve|title=Up Close and Personal: An Unexpected Sitting with Chuck Close|url=http://www.vogue.com/culture/article/becoming-art-an-unexpected-sitting-with-chuck-close/#1|work=Vogue|publisher=Conde Nast|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109063111/http://www.vogue.com/culture/article/becoming-art-an-unexpected-sitting-with-chuck-close/#1|archivedate=2014-01-09|df=}}</ref> In the same year work by Close was also sold to benefit the [[Lunchbox Fund]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Feedie Foodies: The Lunchbox Fund's 2013 Benefit|url=http://www.vogue.com/parties/the-lunchbox-funds-fall-fete/|work=Vogue|publisher=Conde Nast|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022020055/http://www.vogue.com/parties/the-lunchbox-funds-fall-fete/|archivedate=2013-10-22|df=}}</ref>
Close was one of eight artists who volunteered in 2013 to participate in President Barack Obama's [[Turnaround Arts initiative]], which aims to improve low-performing schools by increasing student "engagement" through the arts. Close mentored 34 students in the sixth through eighth grades at Roosevelt School in [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]], one of eight schools in the nation to participate in this public-private partnership developed in cooperation with the U.S. [[Department of Education]] and the White House [[Domestic Policy Council]]. Close was honored by mayor Bill Finch with a key to the city at the November 7 reception at the [[Housatonic Community College]] Museum of Art, where five of Close's watercolor prints were exhibited alongside artwork by students participating in the program.<ref>{{cite web|title=Finch welcomes artist Chuck Close to Park City|url=http://www.thebridgeportnews.com/6993/finch-welcomes-artist-chuck-close-to-park-city/|work=The Bridgeport News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110150721/http://www.thebridgeportnews.com/6993/finch-welcomes-artist-chuck-close-to-park-city/|archivedate=2013-11-10|df=}}</ref>
==In the media== In 1998, [[PBS]] broadcast documentary filmmaker Marion Cajori's [[Emmy]]-nominated short, "Chuck Close: A Portrait in Progress."<ref>[[Roberta Smith]] (August 29, 2006), [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/29/obituaries/29cajori.html Marion Cajori, 56, Filmmaker Who Explored Artistic Process, Dies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123213428/http://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/29/obituaries/29cajori.html |date=2015-01-23 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> In 2007, Cajori made "Chuck Close", a full-length expansion of the first film.<ref>Matt Zoller Seitz (December 26, 2007), [https://movies.nytimes.com/2007/12/26/movies/26chuc.html Master Portraitist, Writ Large Himself] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101015184604/http://movies.nytimes.com/2007/12/26/movies/26chuc.html |date=2010-10-15 }} ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> British art critic Christopher Finch wrote a biography, ''Chuck Close: Life'', which was published in 2010, a sequel of sorts to Finch's 2007 book, ''Chuck Close: Work'', a career-spanning monograph.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gottlieb|first=Benjamin|title=Art Books In Review: How We Talk About Chuck Close|journal=The Brooklyn Rail|date=January 2011|url=http://brooklynrail.org/2010/12/artseen/art-books-in-review-how-we-talk-about-chuck-close|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20120430155831/http://brooklynrail.org/2010/12/artseen/art-books-in-review-how-we-talk-about-chuck-close|archivedate=2012-04-30|df=}}</ref>
Close appeared on ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' on August 12, 2010, where he admitted he watches the show every night.

'''Clean Break''' is a [[feminism|feminist]] [[theatre company]]<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.artsprofessional.co.uk/magazine/276/case-study/working-women |title=Working with women: Clean Break | ArtsProfessional |first=Naomi |last=Joseph |work=artsprofessional.co.uk |year=2015|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/funding/funded-projects/case-studies/clean-break/ |title=Clean Break | Arts Council |first= |last= |work=artscouncil.org.uk |year=2015 |accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref> started in 1979 by Jenny Hicks and Jackie Holborough, whilst inmates of [[HMP Askham Grange]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2010/nov/08/clean-break-women-prison-theatre |title=Clean Break and the invisible women | Stage | The Guardian |first=Lyn |last=Gardner |work=theguardian.com |year=2015 |accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref> Upon their release they formed the theatre company, in order to tell the hidden stories of women in prison. The company also organises residencies in women's prisons in the UK, using directors, playwrights and actors to work with inmates to create their own work. In 1998 the company moved from its base in [[Camden Town|Camden]] to a refurbished building in [[Kentish Town]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/culture-professionals-network/culture-professionals-blog/2013/mar/13/restorative-theatre-clean-break-offenders |title=Restorative theatre: working inside out with prisons and offenders | Culture professionals network | The Guardian |first=Lucy |last=Perman |work=theguardian.com |year=2015 |accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/voluntary-sector-network/2014/oct/01/charity-awards-2014-shortlist |title=Charity Awards 2014 - shortlist | Voluntary Sector Network | The Guardian |first= |last= |work=theguardian.com |year=2015 |accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref>
The playwright [[Lucy Kirkwood]], is writer in residence at Clean Break.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.playscripts.com/playwrights/bios/907 |title=Lucy Kirkwood | Playscripts, Inc. |first= |last=|work=playscripts.com |year=2015 |accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref> Productions include [[Sam Holcroft]]'s ''Dancing Bears'' at the Soho Theatre,<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-reviews/8138516/Charged-Clean-Break-Soho-Theatre-review.html |title=Charged, Clean Break, Soho Theatre, review - Telegraph |first=Daisy |last=Bowie-Sell |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date= |publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group|TMG]] |location=[[London, UK|London]] |issn=0307-1235 |oclc=49632006 |accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref> ''Little on the inside'' by Alice Birch at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe|Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2014]]<ref>http://everything-theatre.co.uk/2013/08/little-on-inside-almeida-theatre.html</ref> and ''Pests'' by [[Vivienne Franzmann]] (a co-production with [[Royal Court Theatre]] & Royal Exchange Theatre 2014.
Clean Break trustee Alice Millest was named Young Board Member of the Year at the 2014 Arts & Business Awards.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://artsandbusiness.bitc.org.uk/awards-ab/35th-awards/alice-millest-cleanbreak |title=Alice Millest & Clean Break | Arts & Business |first=Alice |last=Millest|work=artsandbusiness.bitc.org.uk |year=2015|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref>
Clean Break were shortlisted for the Guardian Charity of the Year Awards in 2014<ref> {{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/voluntary-sector-network/2014/oct/01/charity-awards-2014-shortlist |title=Charity Awards 2014 - shortlist | Voluntary Sector Network | The Guardian |first= |last= |work=theguardian.com |year=2015 |accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref> and received a Highly Commended Award from the [[Longford Trust]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.longfordtrust.org/prize_details.php?id=15 |title=Longford Trust - Longford Prize Winner: Prisoners' Advice Service (PAS) |first= |last= |work=longfordtrust.org |year=2015 |accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

'''Colin John Radford''' (27 February 1935 – 9 April 2001) was an English philosopher who worked primarily in [[aesthetics]] but had interests in a wide variety of philosophical topics. He is best known for describing the [[paradox of fiction]] in the 1975 essay "How Can We Be Moved by the Fate of [[Anna Karenina]]?" and developing the paradox in a number of subsequent essays.<ref>[http://www.iep.utm.edu/fict-par/ The Paradox of Fiction], Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy</ref><ref>[http://www.aesthetics-online.org/memorials/index.php?memorials_id=11 Colin Radford Remembered] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201094530/http://www.aesthetics-online.org/memorials/index.php?memorials_id=11 |date=2014-02-01 }}, Bob Sharpe, Aesthetics Online</ref>
Radford was a pupil at [[Thornbury Grammar School]], then studied at [[London School of Economics]] and the [[University of Bristol]]. He studied for a doctorate under [[Gilbert Ryle]] at Oxford before taking a position at the [[University of Kent]], where he taught until his retirement in 1992. He was a visiting lecturer at the [[University of California at Berkeley|University of California , Berkeley]], the [[University of Illinois]], and [[Queensland University]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2001/may/22/guardianobituaries.humanities|title=Colin Radford|author=Tony Skillen|work=The Guardian|date=22 May 2001|accessdate=18 January 2014}}</ref>

[[File:Fort Dansborg.JPG|thumb|224x224px|[[Denmark|Danish]] Fort Dansborg at [[Tranquebar]], built by [[Ove Gedde]] in 1620.]] '''Colonial architecture''' is an architectural style from a mother country that has been incorporated into the buildings of settlements or colonies in distant locations. Colonists frequently built settlements that synthesized the architecture of their countries of origin with the design characteristics of their new lands, creating hybrid designs.{{cite book |last=Guaita |first=Ovidio |year=1999 |title=On distant shores: colonial houses around the world |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8BRUAAAAMAAJ&q=world+colonial+architecture&dq=world+colonial+architecture&hl=en&sa=X&ei=obfkUqKfFIqKiQfB2oFA&redir_esc=y |location= |publisher=Monacelli Press |isbn=9781580930512 |accessdate=January 26, 2014 }} Below are links to specific articles about colonial architecture, specifically the [[Colony#Modern historical examples|modern colonies]]: ==Spanish colonial architecture== {{Details|Category: Spanish Colonial architecture}} [[Spanish Colonial architecture]] is still found in the former colonies of the [[Spanish Empire]] in the [[Americas]] and in the [[Philippines]]. In Mexico, it is found in the [[Historic center of Mexico City]], [[Puebla]], [[Zacatecas, Zacatecas|Zacatecas]], [[Querétaro]], [[Guanajuato, Guanajuato|Guanajuato]], and [[Morelia]]. [[Antigua Guatemala]] in [[Guatemala]] is also known for its well-preserved Spanish colonial style architecture. Other cities known for Spanish colonial heritage are [[Ciudad Colonial]] of [[Santo Domingo]], the ports of [[Cartagena, Colombia]], and [[Old San Juan]] in [[Puerto Rico]]. ;North America [[File:Catedral de México.jpg|thumb|right|Under construction for more than two centuries, the [[Mexico City Metropolitan Cathedral]] is a mixture of three styles that predominated during the colonial era: [[Renaissance architecture|Renaissance]], [[Baroque architecture|Baroque]] and [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassic]].]] *[[Viceroyalty of New Spain]] **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in Mexico}} ***[[New Spanish Baroque]] **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in the United States}} **[[Spanish Colonial Revival architecture]] ;Caribbean *[[Spanish West Indies]] **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in Cuba}} **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in the Dominican Republic}} **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in Puerto Rico}} ;South America *[[Viceroyalty of Peru]], [[Viceroyalty of New Granada]], and [[Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata]] **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in Argentina}} **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in Chile}} **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in Colombia}} **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in Peru}} **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in Venezuela}} *{{C|Spanish missions in South America}} **{{C|Spanish missions in Bolivia}} **[[File:Paoay.JPG|thumb|219x219px|Paoay Church Ilocos Sur Philippines is a fine example of Spanish [[Earthquake Baroque]] only found in the Philippines]]{{C|Spanish missions in Brazil}} **{{C|Spanish missions in Paraguay}} ;Asia *[[Spanish East Indies]] **{{C|Spanish Colonial architecture in the Philippines}} **[[Earthquake Baroque]] **[[Bahay na Bato]] ==Portuguese colonial architecture== [[File:Mozambique n2.jpg|thumb|right|Church of Santo António;
b. 1498, [[Mozambique]]]] [[Portuguese colonial architecture]] is most visible in [[Brazil]], [[Madeira]], [[Architecture of Africa|North Africa and Sub-Saharan Africa]], [[Macau]], Malaysian city of [[Malacca]], city of [[Goa]], [[Moluccas]], and [[Java]]. *Asia **{{C|Portuguese Colonial architecture in India}} **{{C|Portuguese Colonial architecture in Sri Lanka}} **[[Sino-Portuguese architecture]] *South America **{{C|Portuguese Colonial architecture in Brazil}} ==British colonial architecture== [[File:Morgan House Kalimpong 2.jpg|thumb|[[Morgan House, Kalimpong|Morgan House]] is a classic example of colonial Victorian era architecture in [[Kalimpong]], India.]] [[File:WestoverPlantationSEGL.jpg|thumb|right|[[Westover Plantation]], an example of Georgian architecture on the eastern [[James River]], in Virginia]] British colonial architecture are most visible in [[North America]], the [[British West Indies]], the [[Far East]], [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]] and [[South Africa]]. *'''North America''' **[[American colonial architecture]] ***[[Federal Architecture]] ***[[First Period]] ***[[Georgian architecture#Colonial Georgian architecture|Colonial Georgian architecture]] **[[Architecture of Canada#Arrival of the Europeans|British colonial architecture in Canada]] *'''South Asia''' **[[Architecture of India#British Colonial Era: 1615 to 1947|British colonial architecture in India]] **[[Architecture of Pakistan#British colonial architecture|British colonial architecture in Pakistan]] **[[Architecture of Sri Lanka#Colonial Period|Colonial architecture in Sri Lanka]] *'''Australia''' **[[Australian residential architectural styles#Old Colonial Period 1788 - c. 1840|Colonial architecture of Australia]] ***[[Federation architecture]] *'''Far East''' **[[Architecture of Hong Kong#European architecture|British colonial architecture in Hong Kong]] **[[Architecture of Singapore#Colonial period|British colonial architecture in Singapore]] ==French colonial architecture== [[File:French quarter.jpg|thumb|right|Gabriel Peyreaux House in New Orleans, built circa 1780 It is an example of [[poteaux-sur-solle]] construction.]] [[French Colonial|French colonial architecture]] are most visible in [[North America]] and [[Indochina]]. *'''Indochina''' *'''North America''' **[[American colonial architecture#French Colonial|French colonial architecture in North America]] *'''South Asia''' **[[Indian architecture#French: 1673 to 1954|French colonial architecture in India]] ==Dutch colonial architecture== [[File:Toko merah Kota Tua.JPG|thumb|right|[[Toko Merah]], an 18th-century Dutch colonial landmark in [[Jakarta]], shows a typically Dutch high sash windows with split shutters.]] [[Architecture of the Netherlands|Dutch colonial architecture]] is most visible in [[Indonesia]] (especially [[Java]] and [[Sumatra]]), the United States, [[South Asia]], and [[South Africa]]. In Indonesia, formerly Dutch East Indies, colonial architecture was studied academically and had developed into a [[New Indies Style|new tropical architecture]] form which emphasizes on conforming to the tropical climate of the Indies and not completely imitating the architectural language of the Dutch colonists. *'''Indonesia''' **[[Colonial architecture of Indonesia|Dutch colonial architecture of Indonesia]] ***[[Dutch Indies country houses|Old Indies Style]] ***[[Indies Empire style]] ***[[New Indies Style]] *'''North America''' **[[American colonial architecture#Dutch Colonial|Dutch colonial architecture in North America]] **[[Dutch Colonial Revival architecture]] *'''South Asia''' **[[Architecture of India#Dutch: 1605 to 1825|Dutch colonial architecture in India]] **[[Architecture of Sri Lanka#Colonial Period|Colonial architecture in Sri Lanka]] *'''South Africa''' **[[Cape Dutch architecture]] ==Italian colonial architecture== [[Italian colonial architecture]] is visible in [[Libya]], [[Eritrea]] and [[Somalia]], and also on the Greek islands of the [[Dodecanese]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.colonialarchitectureproject.org Website on colonial architecture with 7,000 pictures of colonial buildings around the world] by [[Gauvin Alexander Bailey]] of [[Queen's University]]] and funded by the [[Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada]] and the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] {{commons category|Colonial architecture|
Colonial architecture|position=left}} [[Category:Colonial architecture| ]] [[Category:Architectural styles]] [[Category:Architectural history]] [[Category:History of European colonialism]]

'''Columbia Artists Management, Inc.''' ('''CAMI''') is an international talent management [[talent agent|agency]].
==History== Based in [[New York City]], it was formed in 1930 as Columbia Concerts Corporation by [[Arthur Judson]] and [[William S. Paley]], the then head of the [[Columbia Broadcasting System]], who helped merge seven independent concert bureaus in the United States.
During its existence, CAMI has represented a very large number of active classical artists worldwide, including singers [[Leontyne Price]], [[Elisabeth Schwarzkopf]], [[Renata Tebaldi]], [[Mario Lanza]], [[Jussi Björling]], [[John McCormack (tenor)|John McCormack]], [[Richard Tucker]], [[Paul Robeson]], and [[George London (bass-baritone)|George London]]; pianists [[Vladimir Horowitz]], [[Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli]], and [[Van Cliburn]]; violinists [[Jascha Heifetz]], [[Yehudi Menuhin]], and [[Tossy Spivakovsky]]; and conductors [[Leonard Bernstein]], [[Herbert von Karajan]], and [[Otto Klemperer]].
Composers [[Sergei Prokofiev]], [[Igor Stravinsky]], and [[Aaron Copland]] were managed by CAMI when they appeared as performers.
British music commentator [[Norman Lebrecht]] has criticized CAMI and Wilford for what Lebrecht deems to be overly pervasive influence of them on conductor salaries and limited time spent by music directors with orchestras.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2001/01/24/banorm24.xml Norman Lebrecht, "Could Silver Fox, the manager of maestros, be losing his grip?". ''Telegraph'', January 2001.]</ref><ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2001/01/17/banorm17.xml Norman Lebrecht, "Baton handover". ''Telegraph'', January 2001.]</ref>
