{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = The Clock | director = [[Christian Marclay]] | released = {{film date|2010|10|15|United Kingdom|df=y}} | runtime = 24 hours | country = United Kingdom | budget = US$100,000 }} '''''The Clock''''' is an art installation by video artist [[Christian Marclay]]. It is a looped 24-hour video [[supercut]] ([[montage (filmmaking)|montage]] of scenes from film and television) that feature clocks or timepieces. The artwork itself functions as a [[clock]]: its presentation is synchronized with the real time, resulting in the time shown in a scene being the actual time.
Marclay developed the idea for ''The Clock'' while working on his 2005 piece ''Screen Play''. With the support of the London-based [[White Cube]] gallery, he assembled a team to find footage, which he edited together over the course of three years. Marclay debuted ''The Clock'' at White Cube's London gallery in 2010. The work garnered critical praise, winning the [[Golden Lion]] at the 2011 [[Venice Biennale]]. Its six editions were purchased by major museums, allowing it to attract a widespread following.
==Content== [[File:The Stranger climax.png|thumb|right|The climax of [[Orson Welles]]' ''[[The Stranger (1946 film)|The Stranger]]'' is featured at midnight.]] After midnight, characters go to bars and drink. Some seek intimacy while others are angry to have been awakened by the phone.<ref name="lacey-globe-mail">{{cite web |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/my-24-hours-of-watching-the-clock/article544839/?page=all |title=My 24 hours of watching The Clock |last=Lacey |first=Liam |date=8 February 2012 |website=[[The Globe and Mail]] |access-date=31 May 2015}}</ref> In the early hours, characters are generally alone or sleeping.<ref name="smith-nyrb">{{cite journal |last=Smith |first=Zadie |authorlink=Zadie Smith |date=28 April 2011 |title=Killing Orson Welles at Midnight |url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2011/apr/28/killing-orson-welles-midnight/ |journal=[[The New York Review of Books]] |pages=14–6 |subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfweekly.com/sanfrancisco/christian-marclays-the-clock-is-the-worlds-most-elaborate-timepiece/Content?oid=2254217 |title=Christian Marclay's 'The Clock' is the World's Most Elaborate Timepiece |last=Curiel |first=Jonathan |date=17 April 2013 |website=[[SF Weekly]] |access-date=30 May 2015}}</ref> Several dream sequences occur between 3 a.m. and 5 a.m.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker">{{cite journal |last=Zalewski |first=Daniel |date=12 March 2012 |title=The Hours |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/03/12/the-hours-daniel-zalewski |journal=[[The New Yorker]] |volume=88 |issue=4 |pages=50–63 |access-date=30 May 2015}}</ref> At around 7 a.m., characters are shown waking up.<ref name="lacey-globe-mail"/> From 9 a.m. to noon, they eat breakfast and have wake-up sex.<ref name="woodward-wsj">{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111903791504576587093709382946 |title=Twenty-Four Hour View Cycle |last=Woodward |first=Richard B. |date=28 September 2011 |website=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |access-date=30 May 2015}}</ref> As noon approaches, a sequence of action scenes build up to bells ringing in ''[[High Noon]]''.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/><ref name="herman-cny">{{cite web |url=http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/culture/2012/07/6234022/punching-my-timecard-weekend-christian-marclays-clock |title=Punching my timecard: a weekend with Christian Marclay's 'The Clock' |last=Herman |first=Sasha |date=18 July 2012 |website=[[Capital New York]] |access-date=30 May 2015}}</ref> The video's pace immediately slows once noon passes.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/>
Between 4 p.m. and 5 p.m., transportation becomes important as characters travel on planes, trains, and automobiles.<ref name="smith-nyrb"/> At 6 p.m., characters eat dinner and have shootouts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://montecristomagazine.com/magazine/winter-2012/time-and-change-in-film |title=Time and Change in Film |last=Turions |first=Cheyanne |date=10 December 2012 |website=MONTECRISTO |access-date=30 May 2015}}</ref> In the evening, they attend parties.<ref name="lacey-globe-mail"/> Around 8 p.m., orchestras and theaters begin their shows.<ref>{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Roberta |date=4 February 2011 |title=As in Life, Timing Is Everything in the Movies |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/04/arts/design/04marclay.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |page=C26 |access-date=1 June 2015 }}</ref> As midnight approaches, the characters become more frantic, throwing tantrums and requesting stays of execution. Screeching violins from multiple clips build up to the moment.<ref name="smith-nyrb"/> At midnight [[Orson Welles]] is impaled on a clock tower in ''[[The Stranger (1946 film)|The Stranger]]'', and [[Big Ben]], a common sight in ''The Clock'', explodes in ''[[V for Vendetta (film)|V for Vendetta]]''.<ref name="smith-nyrb"/><ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/>
==Production==
===Conception=== ''The Clock'' was conceived in 2005 while Marclay was working on the video score ''Screen Play''. He realised that he needed a way for musicians to synchronise with film footage. An assistant at the [[Eyebeam Art and Technology Center]] brought him footage of clocks, and Marclay began wondering if it was possible to find footage of every minute of the day.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Toop |first=David |authorlink=David Toop |date=October 2011 |title=Painting in Slang |journal=[[The Wire (magazine)|The Wire]] |issue=332 |pages=41–95}}</ref> He kept the idea secret for several years, concerned that someone else would poach his idea.<ref name="johnson-lat">{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/may/18/entertainment/la-et-clock-20110518 |title=For Christian Marclay, 'The Clock' continues to tick |last=Johnson |first=Reed |date=18 May 2011 |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |access-date=2 June 2015}}</ref> After his partner Lydia Yee accepted a position at the [[Barbican Centre]], Marclay moved from New York to London in mid 2007. There he proposed the film to the White Cube gallery, unsure of the project's feasibility. He received a budget of over US$100,000, covered in part by the [[Paula Cooper Gallery]].<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/>
===Development=== [[File:Night of the Living Dead - Ten Minutes to Three.webm|thumb|left|Not all scenes show a clock, such as one from ''[[Night of the Living Dead]]'' announcing "It's ten minutes to three."]] The first several months of production were intended to show that Marclay would be able to find enough material to achieve his vision. White Cube helped him assemble a team of six people to watch DVDs and copy scenes with clocks or time. Marclay himself was often unfamiliar with the source works. They used a [[Google Spreadsheet]] to record and search through clips. As the number of scenes available increased, Marclay was able to start working on transitions between scenes.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/> Working in [[Final Cut Pro]], he edited clips together, standardising the video formats and smoothing the audio.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://filmmakermagazine.com/48134-christian-marclays-the-clock |title=Christian Marclay's ''The Clock'' |last=Bowen |first=Peter |date=12 July 2012 |website=[[Filmmaker (magazine)|Filmmaker]] |access-date=30 May 2015}}</ref> He cited [[Bruce Conner]]'s "odd transitions" as an influence on his editing. Marclay wanted to include more outlandish, melodramatic clips but worried that it would be exhausting over a long period. He instead focused on incidental moments; his head assistant Paul Anton Smith explained that Marclay wanted to show scenes that were "banal and plain but visually interesting." One assistant who focused heavily on scenes of violence was fired, and the remaining assistants began to specialise in individual [[film genre]]s.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/>
After six months, Marclay presented White Cube with several extended sequences, confident that he would eventually be able to finish the project. The footage began taking up too much capacity, so he worked on two [[Power Mac G5]]s with footage split by time of day. Marclay organised files by hour, which became like chapters for him. Each folder suggested different themes to him, allowing him to form loose narratives. He spent three years editing scenes together.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/> Some of the scenes not selected for ''The Clock'' became a part of his 2012 performance piece ''Everyday''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/9571926/Christian-Marclay-arts-man-of-the-moment.html |title=Christian Marclay: art's man of the moment |last=Davies |first=Lucy |date=1 October 2012 |website=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |access-date=31 May 2015}}</ref>
In mid 2010, Marclay recruited Quentin Chiappetta, a sound designer with whom he had worked before, to work on the audio for ''The Clock''. He saved files to disc and sent them to Chiappetta so that the films' soundtracks could be [[equalization (audio)|equalised]]. By September Marclay realised that hundreds of the audio transitions were lacking, with White Cube set to premiere ''The Clock'' the following month. Because of his background as a DJ, he did not want to use simple [[fade (audio engineering)|fade]]s between clips. He went to Chiappetta's MediaNoise studio in [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn]], where the two worked on the soundtrack using [[Pro Tools]]. In some cases, they created completely new audio for the scenes.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/><ref name="thornton-economist">{{cite web |url=http://www.economist.com/node/16885826 |title=Slave to the rhythm |last=Thornton |first=Sarah |authorlink=Sarah Thornton |date=25 August 2010 |website=[[The Economist]] |access-date=31 May 2015}}</ref> During the first week of ''The Clock''{{'}}s exhibition, Marclay continued fixing continuity errors and working on the audio.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.art-it.asia/u/admin_ed_feature_e/yvKBQHCwb9cmLxYnEO2l |title=Christian Marclay: The Clock |last=Maerkle |first=Andrew |date=24 December 2010 |website=ART iT |access-date=19 June 2015}}</ref> The final product used around 12,000 clips.<ref name="borrelli-chicago-tribune">{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/ct-the-clock-walker-museum-20140726-column.html |title=Time is ticking at 'The Clock' exhibit in Minneapolis |last=Borrelli |first=Christopher |date=25 July 2014 |website=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=30 May 2015}}</ref> Because of its size, Marclay enlisted professor Mick Grierson to create a program that plays the separate audio and video tracks, synchronised with the current time.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/> The program continues running while a museum is closed so that it remains synchronised.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/a-24-hour-movie-that-may-be-the-biggest-and-best-supercut-ever-9430/?all |title=A 24-Hour Movie That May Be the Biggest (and Best) Supercut Ever |last=Stromberg |first=Joseph |date=28 December 2012 |website=[[Smithsonian (magazine)|Smithsonian]] |access-date=31 May 2015}}</ref>
==Release== Marclay made six editions of ''The Clock'', plus two [[artist's proof]]s.<ref name="woodward-wsj"/> Five copies were designated to be sold to institutions for US$467,500 each under the condition that ''The Clock'' can't be played in more than one location at the same time.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2018/sep/10/christian-marclay-the-clock-tate-modern-london|title='It's impossible!' – Christian Marclay and the 24-hour clock made of movie clips|last=Bradshaw|first=Peter|date=2018-09-10|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}}</ref> The last copy was sold to hedge fund manager [[Steven A. Cohen]] for an undisclosed amount.<ref name="balsom-framework">{{cite journal |last=Balsom |first=Erika |date=September 2013 |title=Around ''The Clock'': Museum and Market |journal=Framework: The Journal of Cinema and Media |publisher=[[Wayne State University Press]] |volume=54 |issue=2 |pages=177–91 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2011/04/last-month-culture-monster-reported-that-the-la-county-museum-of-art-wasworking-to-acquire-christian-marclays-2010.html|title=LACMA acquires 'The Clock' by Christian Marclay and a sculpture by Ai Weiwei through annual collecting event [UPDATED]|date=18 April 2011|publisher=}}</ref> Within a day of premiering ''The Clock'', White Cube received a host of offers from museums, some of which purchased copies jointly.<ref name="whyte-canadian-art">{{cite web |url=http://canadianart.ca/features/patrons-in-time/ |title=How Toronto Patrons Jay Smith and Laura Rapp Brought The Clock to Canada |last=Whyte |first=Murray |date=17 September 2012 |website=[[Canadian Art (magazine)|Canadian Art]] |access-date=8 July 2015}}</ref> The sale became one of the largest purchases of [[video art]] and one of the highest purchases to happen on the [[art valuation#Primary and secondary markets|primary market]].<ref name="balsom-framework"/> The work owned by the New York collectors Jill and Peter Kraus, is a promised gift to the [[Museum of Modern Art]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Vogel |first=Carol |date=20 April 2012 |title=Ai Weiwei Retrospective at the Hirshhorn |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/20/arts/design/hirshhorn-museum-plans-ai-weiwei-retrospective-in-october.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |page=C28 |access-date=5 June 2015}}</ref> In 2011, [[Steve Tisch]] pledged the money needed to buy the work for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2011/04/last-month-culture-monster-reported-that-the-la-county-museum-of-art-wasworking-to-acquire-christian-marclays-2010.html |title=LACMA acquires 'The Clock' by Christian Marclay and a sculpture by Ai Weiwei through annual collecting event |last=Finkel |first=Jori |date=18 April 2011 |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |access-date=5 June 2015}}</ref> One month later, the [[National Gallery of Canada]] and the [[Boston Museum of Fine Arts]], announced the acquisition of another copy.<ref name="whyte-canadian-art"/> In February 2012, yet another version was acquired jointly by the [[Tate]] in London, the [[Centre Pompidou]] in Paris, and the [[Israel Museum]] in Jerusalem.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2012/feb/01/tate-buys-christian-marclay-clock |title=Tate buys timeshare in Christian Marclay's Clock |last=Kennedy |first=Maev |date=1 February 2012 |website=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=5 June 2015}}</ref>
===Exhibition=== Marclay originally considered making ''The Clock'' as a [[public art]] piece. However, difficulty with lighting and sound made it impractical.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/> Marclay gave museums specifications for the exhibitions' screening rooms.<ref name="borrelli-chicago-tribune"/> He wanted the video to be projected onto a {{convert|21|x|12|foot|m}} screen, in a room with white [[IKEA]] couches.<ref name="krauss-october">{{cite journal |last=Krauss |first=Rosalind E. |authorlink=Rosalind E. Krauss |date=May 2011 |title=Clock Time |journal=[[October (journal)|October]] |publisher=[[MIT Press]] |issue=136 |pages=213–7}}</ref><ref name="russell-framework">{{cite journal |last=Russell |first=Catherine |date=September 2013 |title=Archival Cinephilia in ''The Clock'' |journal=Framework: The Journal of Cinema and Media |publisher=[[Wayne State University Press]] |volume=54 |issue=2 |pages=243–58}}</ref> Presenting the piece became a source of friction between Marclay and some museums. ''[[The Art Newspaper]]'' reported that [[LACMA]]'s director [[Michael Govan]] wanted to project it onto the museum, though LACMA denied suggesting it be projected outside.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/><ref>{{cite journal |last=Burns |first=Charlotte |date=April 2011 |title=Coming soon? Movie montage for LA |journal=[[The Art Newspaper]] |volume=20 |issue=223 |page=1}}</ref> Marclay disapproved of other screening locations suggested by the Boston Museum of Fine Arts and the Tate.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/> In order to ensure that the full video would be exhibited, he required that museums agree to be open for all 24 hours at some point during its run.<ref name="borrelli-chicago-tribune"/>
''The Clock'' premiered 15 October 2010 at White Cube's gallery in central London.<ref name="smith-nyrb"/> Since then, it has attracted hundreds of thousands of visitors and found crossover success beyond art patrons.<ref>{{cite news |last=Aspden |first=Peter |date=24 January 2015 |title=Playing to the gallery |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/f5263964-a164-11e4-8d19-00144feab7de.html |newspaper=[[Financial Times]] |page=1 |access-date=3 June 2015 }}</ref><ref name="romney-sight-sound">{{cite journal |last=Romney |first=Jonathan |date=11 May 2011 |title=The Clock: What time is it where? |url=http://old.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/feature/49723 |journal=[[Sight & Sound]] |volume=20 |issue=5 |pages=30–1 |access-date=1 June 2015}}</ref> The Paula Cooper Gallery exhibited it in early 2011, where it attracted 11,500 visitors over the course of a month. In mid 2012, the [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts]] showed it to 18,000 people over six weeks.<ref name="miller-aia">{{cite web |url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-features/news/moma-clocks-40000-visitors-to-marclay-video/ |title=MoMA Clocks 40,000+ Visitors to Marclay Video |last=Miller |first=Leigh Anne |date=23 January 2013 |website=[[Art in America]] |access-date=31 May 2015}}</ref> MoMA heavily promoted its run with a silent disco, a New Years celebration, and a dedicated @TheClockatMoMA account on [[Twitter]].<ref name="balsom-framework"/> The month-long exhibition drew over 40,000 people.<ref name="miller-aia"/>
===Copyright=== When he started to make ''The Clock'', Marclay expected that copyright would not be a substantial obstacle, theorizing that "If you make something good and interesting and not ridiculing someone or being offensive, the creators of the original material will like it."<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/> He did not get copyright clearances for any of the films used.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/review/time-lord-christian-marclay-is-one-to-watch-at-the-mca/story-fn9n8gph-1226299070960 |title=Time lord Christian Marclay is one to watch at the MCA |last=Westwood |first=Matthew |date=17 March 2012 |website=[[The Australian]] |access-date=31 May 2015}}</ref> He stated that although his use was illegal, "most would consider it [[fair use]]."<ref name="thornton-economist"/> Because of the film's copyright status, museums have offered it as part of their general admission instead of charging for separate tickets.<ref name="borrelli-chicago-tribune"/>
==Reception== ''The Clock'' has been described as "addictive" and "mesmerizing". ''[[The Guardian]]'' called it "a masterpiece of our times".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2011/apr/07/christian-marclay-the-clock |title=Christian Marclay's The Clock: a masterpiece of our times |last=Bradshaw |first=Peter |authorlink=Peter Bradshaw |date=7 April 2011 |website=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=30 May 2015}}</ref> [[Chris Petit]] complimented its "edge-of-hysteria relentlessness, the anti-narrative drive", and the simple concept, commenting that he wished he had thought of the idea himself.<ref name="sinclair-petit-film-comment">{{cite journal |last1=Sinclair |first1=Iain |authorlink1=Iain Sinclair |last2=Petit |first2=Chris |authorlink2=Chris Petit |date=May 2011 |title=Time Pieces |journal=[[Film Comment]] |publisher=[[Film Society of Lincoln Center]] |volume=47 |issue=3 |pages=50–7}}</ref> In ''[[The New York Review of Books]]'', [[Zadie Smith]] stated that ''The Clock'' "is neither bad nor good, but sublime, maybe the greatest film you have ever seen".<ref name="smith-nyrb"/> ''[[Newsweek]]'' named Marclay one of the ten most important artists of today.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/10-most-important-artists-today-67947 |title=The 10 Most Important Artists of Today |last=Gopnik |first=Blake |date=5 June 2011 |website=[[Newsweek]] |subscription=yes |access-date=25 June 2011}}</ref> He was included in the 2012 [[Time 100|''Time'' 100]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://time.com/42520/christian-marclay/ |title=2012 TIME 100 Includes Artist Christian Marclay |last=Dyer |first=Geoff |authorlink=Geoff Dyer |date=18 April 2012 |website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |access-date=31 May 2015}}</ref>
At the 2011 [[Venice Biennale]], Marclay was recognised as the best artist in the official exhibition, winning the Golden Lion for ''The Clock''. Accepting the Golden Lion, Marclay invoked [[Andy Warhol]], thanking the jury "for giving ''The Clock'' its fifteen minutes".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/123932/artinfos-rundown-of-the-winners-of-the-golden-and-silver-lions |title=ARTINFO's Rundown of the Winners of the Golden and Silver Lions at the 54th Venice Biennale |last1=Goldstein |first1=Andrew M. |last2=Halperin |first2=Julia |date=6 June 2011 |publisher=[[Artinfo]] |access-date=30 May 2015}}</ref> The film also won in the "Best Editing" category at the [[Boston Society of Film Critics Awards 2011]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/11/idUS201794256320111211 |title='The Artist' Named Best Picture by Boston Film Critics |date=11 December 2011 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |access-date=30 May 2015}}</ref>
==Interpretations== ''The Clock'' reveals its plot largely through the use of [[cutaway shot]]s. A shot indicating the time is followed by a [[reaction shot]] with a character's emotional response, often one of anxiety, fear, or boredom.<ref name="krauss-october"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2011/09/20/a_watched_clock_globe_reporters_spend_24_hours_watching_christian_marclays_film/?page=full |title=Tick-tock: A watched 'Clock' |date=20 September 2011 |publisher=[[Boston.com]] |access-date=3 June 2015}}</ref> Petit remarked that the impact of repeated reactions lacking context "comes over as incredibly weird".<ref name="sinclair-petit-film-comment"/> The sequence [[interpellation (philosophy)|interpellates]] viewers into ''The Clock''{{'}}s flow, and they often experience a detached, hypnotic effect.<ref name="russell-framework"/>
Marclay viewed ''The Clock'' as a ''[[memento mori]]''.<ref name="thornton-economist"/> In contrast to the escapism that cinema provides, ''The Clock'' draws attention to how much time the audience has spent watching it.<ref name="johnson-lat"/> As they spend more time with the film, its actors reappear at various points in their careers. To make this theme more explicit, Marclay included symbols of time and death in connecting shots. These included sunsets; withering flowers; and burning cigarettes, which he described as "the twentieth-century symbol of time", a modern version of burning candles.<ref name="zalewski-new-yorker"/><ref name="romney-sight-sound"/> Marclay included shots of turntables and vinyl records not only as a representation of "capturing time, trying to hold it back", but also as a self-reference to his earlier works that used vinyl.<ref name="romney-sight-sound"/>
===Relation to other works=== Marclay made several forays into video art that informed ''The Clock''. His 1995 film ''Telephones'' forms a narrative out of clips from [[Hollywood film]]s where characters use a telephone.<ref name="gonzalez-marclay">{{cite book |last1=González |first1=Jennifer |last2=Gordon |first2=Kim |authorlink2=Kim Gordon |last3=Higgs |first3=Matthew |authorlink3=Matthew Higgs |date=June 2005 |title=Christian Marclay |publisher=[[Phaidon Press]] |page=61 |isbn=978-0-7148-4374-2 }}</ref> It was a link between Marclay's [[audio art|audio]] and video art, and its discontinuous structure was a template for ''The Clock''. ''Telephones'' broke using a telephone into several discrete steps, each reenacted by multiple films, similar to sequences in ''The Clock'' where the act of sleeping or waking is demonstrated by one character after another.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Fowler |first=Catherine |date=September 2013 |title=''The Clock'': Gesture and Cinematic Replaying |journal=Framework: The Journal of Cinema and Media |publisher=[[Wayne State University Press]] |volume=54 |issue=2 |pages=226–42 }}</ref> His 1998 film ''Up and Out'' combines video from [[Michelangelo Antonioni]]'s ''[[Blowup]]'' with audio from [[Brian De Palma]]'s ''[[Blow Out]]''. It was an early experiment in the effect of synchronization, where viewers naturally attempted to find intersections between the two works, and it developed the editing style that Marclay employs for ''The Clock''.<ref name="gonzalez-marclay"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.artnews.com/2012/07/10/its-about-time/ |title=It's About Time |last=Pollack |first=Barbara |date=10 July 2012 |website=[[ARTnews]] |access-date=5 June 2015}}</ref> His 2002 installation ''Video Quartet'' is a 13-minute video with four continuous screens of clips from commercial films. Its combinations of coinciding sounds and images were a model for the [[synchronicity]] of ''The Clock''.<ref name="krauss-october"/>
''The Clock'' has been viewed as an extension of similar compilations, particularly by Christoph Girardet. Girardet's 1999 ''Phoenix Tapes'', a collaboration with [[Matthias Müller (filmmaker)|Matthias Müller]], is composed of footage from [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s films. It arranges them into clusters to illustrate Hitchcock's techniques and motifs. Girardet and Müller use low-quality footage from VHS tapes to draw attention to their appropriation. In contrast, Marclay seeks to replicate Hollywood production through high-quality footage with standardised sound production and aspect ratios.<ref name="horwatt-framework">{{cite journal |last=Horwatt |first=Eli |date=September 2013 |title=On ''The Clock'' and Christian Marclay's Instrumental Logic of Appropriation |journal=Framework: The Journal of Cinema and Media |publisher=[[Wayne State University Press]] |volume=54 |issue=2 |pages=208–25}}</ref> Girardet's 2003 work ''60 Seconds (analog)'' is a 60-second film intended to be played on a loop. 60 brief shots show the hands of watches and clocks counting the seconds. Girardet wanted to show how interchangeable the cinema footage could be.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monopol-magazin.de/ist-christian-marclays-clock-ein-plagiat |title=Ist Christian Marclays 'The Clock' ein Plagiat? |last=Hinrichsen |first=Jens |date=10 October 2011 |website=Monopol |access-date=5 June 2015 |language=German |trans-title=Is Christian Marclay's 'The Clock' plagiarism?}}</ref> Müller described it as ''The Clock'' "in a conceptual, minimalist nutshell."<ref name="horwatt-framework"/> In 2005 [[Étienne Chambaud]] presented ''L'Horloge'', a piece of software that displays the time using images of clocks in films. Chambaud's use of still images give ''L'Horloge'' a slower, more regular pace, whereas ''The Clock'' experiments with the rhythm of commercial films.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.vice.com/read/komp-laint-dept-marclay |title=Komplaint Dept. |last=Nickas |first=Bob |date=26 January 2012 |website=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] |access-date=5 June 2015}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{BLP sources|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox fashion designer |name = Thierry Mugler |image = Manfred Thierry Mugler.jpg |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1948|12|21|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Strasbourg]], France |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |nationality = French |education = |label_name = |awards = |known_for = Angel fragrance, perfumes |occupation = Fashion designer, perfume designer }}
'''Thierry Mugler''' ({{IPA-fr|tjɛʁi myɡle}}; born 21 December 1948) is a [[French people|French]] [[fashion designer]].
==Early life and education== Mugler was born in [[Strasbourg, France]]. His passion led him to focus more on drawing than on school, {{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} and at the age of 9, he began to study classical dance.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} By 14, he joined the ballet corps for the Rhin Opera ([[Opéra national du Rhin]]).<ref name="cirquedusoleil.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.cirquedusoleil.com/en/press/kits/shows/zumanity/resources/creators/thierry-mugler.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111018132508/http://www.cirquedusoleil.com/en/press/kits/shows/zumanity/resources/creators/thierry-mugler.aspx |archivedate=18 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
At the same time, Mugler began formal [[interior design]] training at the [[Haute école des arts du Rhin|Strasbourg School of Decorative Arts]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}
==Career== At the age of 24, Mugler moved to [[Paris]], France. He began designing clothes for Parisian boutique, Gudule. At 26, Mugler, who was working as a freelance designer, began to design for a variety of large [[ready-to-wear]] [[fashion house]]s in [[Paris]], [[Milan]], [[London]] and [[Barcelona]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}
In 1973, Mugler created his first personal collection called "Café de Paris". The style of the collection was both sophisticated and urban. Melka Tréanton, a powerful fashion editor, helped to launch his career. In 1976, she asked him to show his work in [[Tokyo]] for an event organized by [[Shiseido]].<ref name="shiseido">{{cite web|url=http://www.shiseido.co.jp/releimg/1790-e.pdf|date=19 August 2010|title=Window Display Exhibition in Paris to Commemorate the 30th Anniversary of Shiseido Cosmetics Sales in France|accessdate=9 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924101406/http://www.shiseido.co.jp/releimg/1790-e.pdf|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 1978, he opened his first Paris boutique at the [[Place des Victoires]] in the [[1st arrondissement of Paris|1er Arrondissement]]). At the same time, Thierry Mugler launched a fashion collection for men. For this collection, he reworked classical masculinity, giving it a definitively modern style. A clean, precise, structured cut which outlined a highly recognizable silhouette: prominent shoulders, both "anatomical and classic", for a dynamically slender look.
During the 1980s and 1990s, Thierry Mugler became an internationally recognized designer, and his collections garnered much commercial success. At the request of the [[Chambre Syndicale de la Haute Couture]], he completed his first [[haute couture]] collection in 1992.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}
He created the famous black dress worn by [[Demi Moore]] in the 1993 movie, ''[[Indecent Proposal]]''.
[[File:Thierry mugler dress.jpg|thumb|right|An evening dress by Thierry Mugler in an [http://www.imamuseum.org/art/collections/artwork/dress-mugler-thierry-0 Indianapolis Museum of Art] exhibit]] [[File:Rainbow dress by Thierry Mugler.jpg|thumb|A dress by Thierry Mugler in an [http://www.imamuseum.org/art/collections/artwork/dress-thierry-mugler Indianapolis Museum of Art] exhibit]] His clothes are identified by their style and their structure. Mugler, over the next two decades created a style that was very much of its time: it was strong, angular, and sometimes almost cruel. Shoulders were wide and padded; waists were wasp-like. Prints were banished: Mugler’s clothes came in solid, dominating colors. Collars had exaggerated points, or flame-like cutouts. The insect kingdom was a constant influence, as were the ladies and gentlemen of film noir. PVC was often used as his material for his runway pieces, used to create space and robot themes.<ref>http://fashion.infomat.com/thierry-mugler-designer.html</ref>
Mugler published his first [[photography]] book in 1988, ''Thierry Mugler, Photographe''. {{citation needed|date=May 2013}} This was followed by a [[monograph]] in 1999 entitled, ''Fashion Fetish Fantasy'' which assembles photos of his creations.
Mugler also directs short films, advertising films and video clips. He regularly designs costumes for musical comedies, concerts, operas and the theatre (including Macbeth for the [[Comédie Française]]). He has worked with [[Robert Altman]] and [[George Michael]] (he directed the video for Michael's "[[Too Funky]]" in 1992). He also directed the first advertising film for one of his fragrances, Alien.
In 2002 Mugler collaborated with the [[Cirque du Soleil]]. He directed "Extravaganza", one of the scenes of [[Zumanity]], and also created all of the costumes and the identity of the characters in the show.
In 2009, Mugler worked as artistic advisor to singer [[Beyoncé]].<ref>[http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/news/fashion/289751/thierry-mugler-to-design-beyonce-tour.html Thierry Mugler to Design Beyonce Tour] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212082019/http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/news/fashion/289751/thierry-mugler-to-design-beyonce-tour.html |date=12 December 2009 }} Marie Claire, 2008. Accessed 29 May 2013.</ref> He created the costumes for her "[[I Am... World Tour]]".<ref name="cirquedusoleil.com"/>
In 2016, Mugler created and directed the music video and staging for [[San Marino]]'s [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016|Eurovision Song Contest]] entry [[I Didn't Know]] performed by Turkish singer [[Serhat (singer)|Serhat]].<ref>http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=san_marino_serhat_presents_i_didnt_know</ref>
In 2008 the Mugler's brand launched Thierry Mugler Beauty, a high-end line of [[cosmetics]].
In September 2010 [[Nicola Formichetti]] was announced to be the [[Creative Director]] of the Thierry Mugler [[brand]]. He changed the brand name to MUGLER, removing the first name, and in January 2011 he launched the revival of the brand's [[menswear]] collection in collaboration with [[Romain Kremer]].<ref>{{Cite web|author=Suzy MENKES|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/18/fashion/on-top-of-the-world.html|title=On top of the world|website=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=30 April 2014}}</ref>
An April 2010 ''[[New York Times]]'' story discussed Mugler's [[cosmetic surgery|cosmetic transformation]]. "[Mugler has] taken to calling himself Manfred and transformed his body...into what is apparently a 240-pound spectacle of muscle and nipple and tattoo..."
With over two years of being the creative director of MUGLER, Formichetti announced in April 2013 that he and the fashion house will be parting ways. Formichetti left MUGLER in to work for the Italian brand [[Diesel (brand)|Diesel]].
In December 2013, House of Mugler announced [[David Koma]] as the [[artistic director]].<ref name="Thierry Mugler Names David Koma Artistic Director">{{cite web | url=http://www.wwd.com/fashion-news/designer-luxury/thierry-mugler-taps-david-koma-7312059?src=n/newsAlert/20131213-1 | title=Thierry Mugler Names David Koma Artistic Director | publisher=WWD | date=12 December 2013 | accessdate=13 December 2013| author=Socha, Miles}}</ref>
===Fragrances=== {{see|Angel (perfume)}} [[File:Angel Men (1413014127).jpg|thumb|right|Angel for men (A*Men)]]
Mugler’s first [[perfume]] appeared in 1992 and was called ''[[Angel (perfume)|Angel]]''. "Angel" contains a combination of praline and [[chocolate]] mixed with a strong accord of [[patchouli]]. It would be a part of a new fragrance type called [[gourmand (fragrance)|gourmand]]. The Angel bottle, a design in the shape of a faceted star, was created by the Brosse Master Glassmakers. Fans of the fragrance include [[Diana Ross]], [[Barbara Walters]], [[Eva Mendes]], and [[Hillary Clinton]].<ref>[http://www.celebrityfragranceguide.com/ http://www.celebrityfragranceguide.com/]</ref>
In 1996 Mugler followed up Angel with a male version named Angel Men or A*Men. This fragrance includes notes of caramel, [[coffee]], vanilla, [[patchouli]], and honey.
In 2005, Alien was created, the second major Thierry Mugler fragrance. Also in 2005, Thierry Mugler launched the Thierry Mugler Perfume Workshops", which are open to the general public and led by specialists of the [[perfumery]] and [[oenology]] world.
Angel and Alien together produce about $280 million in sales annually.<ref name="NYtimes">[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/02/fashion/02MUGLER.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 Thierry Mugler, Still Creating a Stir] NY Times. 2010. Accessed 29 May 2013.</ref>
In 2010, the fragrance Womanity was released by the house of Mugler.<ref>womanity.com</ref>
Mugler's newest fragrance, Angel Muse, was released in 2015.
In 2006, Thierry Mugler completed a project for the launch of [[Tom Tykwer]]'s film "Perfume". In collaboration with the IFF company, Thierry Mugler created a box set of fifteen compositions.
During 2007, still following the metamorphosis theme, Mugler launched Mirror, Mirror, a collection of five fragrances, created as "perfume-trickery" to "enhance one’s presence".
==Personal life== Mugler is openly gay, and is a longtime [[bodybuilder]].<ref>[https://www.vice.com/read/thierry-mugler Thierry Mugler] vice.com/</ref>

[[File:Tomba di Philippe Pot.JPG|thumb|440px|Tomb of Philippe Pot, c. 1477–80]] [[File:Détail du tombeau de Philippe Pot (17863220888).jpg|340px|thumb|Detail of the pleurants]] The '''Tomb of Philippe Pot''' is a 15th-century [[Funerary art|funerary monument]] commissioned by [[Philippe Pot]] (d. 1493), royal steward of [[Duchy of Burgundy|Burgundy]] under [[Louis XI]], between c. 1477–80 for his burial at the chapel of Saint-Jean-Baptiste in [[Cîteaux Abbey]], south of [[Dijon]].<ref>Sadler, xi</ref>
It consists of eight life-sized [[pleurants]], represented as solemn and hooded [[pallbearer]]s carrying Philippe's recumbent [[effigy]] towards its final resting place.<ref name = "Sadler22">Sadler, 22</ref> Made of polychromed [[limestone]], paint, gold and lead, it measures 181 (width) x 260 (height) x 167 (depth) cm. No definitive attributions have been made as to the artists and craftsmen who created the work, but [[Antoine Le Moiturier]] is often suggested to have produced the mourners.
The tomb was plundered during the French revolution, and in the 19th century positioned in private gardens in hotels in Dijon. It has been in the collection of the [[Louvre|Musée du Louvre]] since 1899, where it is on permanent display.
==Description== [[Philip the Bold]] (1363–1404) commissioned the first of the [[Duchy of Burgundy|Burgundian]] tombs in the latter part of the 14th century, hiring [[Claus Sluter]] as sculptor, whose distinctive style in which many small pleurants are positioned surrounding the effigy, was copied for the next century. Philippe Pot (1428–1493), royal stewart and seneschal to the Dukes of Burgundy, was raised at the Burgundian court, where he was educated. His tomb follows the tradition of the earliest ducal tombs, with Sluter's influence evident in the presence of mourners – or pleurants. As art historian Donna Sadler writes, a century after Sluter's work, in Pot's tomb "the ''pleurants'' have taken steroids and become life-sized, bearing the effigy upon their shoulders".<ref name = "Sadler22"/>
Philippe Pot reposes on a limestone plate or slab, and is dressed in a [[Knight|Knightly]] helmet and armor with a [[Gilding|gilded]] breastplate. His head rests on a cushion, his eyes are open and his hands are clasped in prayer. A sword lies to his side while a lion rests at his feet. The mourners, whose carved forms seem influenced by the Dutch sculptor Claus Sluter,<ref>Hourihane, 357</ref> are carved in black stone, and dressed full length black hooded [[Religious habit|habit]]s. Each bows their head in grief, and each bears an individually designed gilded heraldic shield, which may refer to Philippe's lineage, making the monument of the "Kinship tomb" type.<ref>McGee Morganstern, 8</ref> The tomb is in good condition, but has been restored in places; a 19th century engraving shows Philippe's hands broken apart.<ref name="ss158">Sterling & Salinger, 158</ref>
[[File:GD-FR-Paris-Louvre-Sculptures034.JPG|thumb|320px|View]]
Its style and scale became influential, because the sculptor transformed the size and placement of''pleurants'', which had been relatively small figures standing in niches around the sarcophagus. Its influence is evidenced by the similar tombs of Louis de Savoisy (d. 1515) and Jacques de Mâlain (d. 1527).<ref>Sadler, 23</ref>
==Attribution== The monument was commissioned to stand over Philippe's grave in the north arm of the chapel's [[transept]]. The artists and craftsmen involved in its production have not been identified, although the French sculptor Antoine Le Moiturier is often suggested as likely to have created the pleurants, based on the facial types and according to art historian Colum Hourihane the "unusually rigid drapery".<ref>Hourihane, 40</ref> Guillaume Chandelier has also been suggested as involved, but there is little concrete evidence.<ref>Hofstatter, 137, 256</ref><ref name="MoF">"[http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=CHERCHER&FIELD_1=REF&VALUE_1=M5037011289 Tomb of Philip Pot, Grand Seneschal of Burgundy]". Portal of the collections of the Museums of France. Retrieved 8 December 2017</ref>
==Provenance== The tomb was seized by the state during the [[French Revolution]], and sold in 1791 to the Duleu Society and Dardelin of Dijon.<ref name="MoF" /> It was acquired in 1808 by Charles Richard de Vesvrotte, lord of [[Ruffey-lès-Beaune]], following a legal case against the state. De Vesvrotte placed the tomb in the garden of his [[hôtel particulier]] (mansion) in Dijon, the [[Hôtel Petit de Ruffey]]. He then temporarily moved it to a castle grounds in his possession, and then relocated to another of his mansion's gardens. It passed to the French National Collections in 1899.<ref name="ss158" />

''The Grove Encyclopedia of Medieval Art and Architecture, Volume 1''. Oxford University Press, 2012. {{ISBN|978-0-1953-9536-5}} * McGee Morganstern, Anne. ''Gothic Tombs of Kinship in France, the Low Countries, and England''. Penn State Press, 2000 * Sadler, Donna. ''Stone, Flesh, Spirit: The Entombment of Christ in Late Medieval Burgundy''. '''"Ubangi Stomp"''' is an American [[rockabilly]] song. Written by Charles Underwood and first released on record by [[Warren Smith (singer)|Warren Smith]] in 1956, the song did not chart, but went on to become a rockabilly standard, covered by many artists. "Ubangi Stomp" – usually Smith's recording – appears on many compilation albums, including ''[[The Sun Records Collection]]'' and ''[[The Best of Bob Dylan's Theme Time Radio Hour]]''.
"Ubangi Stomp" is a straightforward [[uptempo]] [[rock and roll]] song; the lyrics, of no great literary depth ("''Ubangi stomp ubangi style / When the beat just drives a cool cat wild''"), tell in [[First-person narrative|first person]] the story of a sailor who goes to Africa ("''I rocked through Africa and... Seen them cats doin' the Ubangi stomp''") and, enamored of the local [[Sub-Saharan African music traditions|music]] and [[African dance|dance]], [[wikt:jump ship|jumps ship]] to [[wikt:go native|go native]] ("''Then the captain said son, we gotta go / I said that's alright, you go right ahead / I'm gonna Ubangi-stomp 'till I roll over dead''"). Some mixing of cultural stereotypes is seen when supposed Native American terms ("heap big", [[Tom-tom drum|tom-tom]]) are mixed into the ostensibly African setting.
The Ubangi Stomp Festival, an annual international exposition of America roots and rockabilly music,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubangistomp.com/en#page-home |title=Ubangi Stomp |publisher=American Roots Promotion |accessdate=February 1, 2015}}</ref> takes its name from the song, as does the Ubangi Stomp Club, a [[Dublin]] organization that organizes and promotes roots concerts and gigs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cattytown.com/directory/listing/ubangi-stomp-club |title=Ubangi Stomp Club |work=Cattytown |accessdate=February 1, 2015}}</ref>
Saxophonist [[Earl Bostic]] released an instrumental piece titled "Ubangi Stomp" in 1954, but this has no relation to Underwood's song beyond the title.<ref>{{cite book |last=Tosches |first=Nick |title=Country: The Twisted Roots of Rock 'n' Roll |publisher=Da Capo Press |page=8 |year=1996 |isbn = 978-0306807138 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ALrR8lHmv44C&pg=PA8}}</ref>
==Notable recordings== *[[Warren Smith (singer)|Warren Smith]] (single) (1956, [[Sun Records|Sun]] #250) *[[Jerry Lee Lewis]], on the album ''[[Jerry Lee Lewis (Jerry Lee Lewis album)|Jerry Lee Lewis]]'' (1958, Sun) *[[The Trashmen]] (single) (1965, Argo #5516) *[[Alice Cooper]], on the album ''[[Lace and Whiskey]]'' (1977, [[Warner Bros.]]) *[[John Prine]], on the album ''[[Pink Cadillac (album)|Pink Cadillac]]'' (1979, [[Asylum Records|Asylum]]) *[[The Cichlids]] on the album ''Be True To Your School'' (1980, TK) *[[The Stray Cats]], on the album ''[[Stray Cats (album)|Stray Cats]]'' (1981, [[Arista Records|Arista]]) *[[Gary Young (Australian musician)|Gary Young]] (single) (1981) *[[The Honeymoon Killers (American band)|The Honeymoon Killers]], on the album ''[[The Honeymoon Killers from Mars]]'' (1984, Fur) *[[The Busters]] (single) (1996) *[[Danny Gatton and Robert Gordon]], on the album ''[[The Humbler]]'' (recorded live in 1981, and released in 1996 as NRG NCD-6842). Danny released a different version on the Danny & The Fat Boys album ''American Music'' (1975, Aladdin) *[[Eddie Hinton]], on the album ''Hard Luck Guy'' (1999, [[Capricorn Records|Capricorn]])
The song has been covered by many other artists, including the Juke Joints (on their album ''20 years''), the Top Cats (on their album ''Full Throttle Rockabilly''), The Slippers (on their album ''Ubangi Stomp''),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://yle.fi/elavaarkisto/artikkelit/slippers_ubangi_stomp_20957.html#media=20963 |title=Slippers: Ubangi Stomp |work=Living Archive |publisher=Yle |accessdate=February 1, 2015}}{{link language|fi}}</ref> [[The Sundowners (band)|The Sundowners]] (on the [[B-side]] of their 1959 single "Snake Eyed Woman"), [[The Velaires]] (on the B-side of their 1961 single "It's Almost Tomorrow"),{{#tag:ref|Mistakenly credited on the label to Earl Bostic as composer|group=note}} [[Bobby Taylor & the Vancouvers|Bobby Taylor]] (on the B-side of his 1962 single "Seven Steps to an Angel"), and others. [[Rory Storm|Rory Storm and the Hurricanes]] recorded the song at [[Abbey Road Studios]] in 1964, but this version was never released.
[[Foghat]] recorded a version during the sessions for their first album, ''[[Foghat (1972 album)|Foghat]]'', but the song was not included on the album.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foghat.com/the_history.htm |title=History |work=Foghat.com |accessdate=January 9, 2017}}</ref> It was included on their 1992 compilation ''Best of Foghat Volume 2'' and on their ''The Definitive Rock Collection'' in 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/ubangi-stomp-mt0026952925 |title=Foghat – Ubangi Stump |work=Allmusic |accessdate=January 9, 2017}}</ref>

{{unreferenced|date=July 2016}}
'''Variable-data publishing (VDP)''' (also known as [[database publishing]]) is a term referring to the output of a variable composition system. While these systems can produce both electronically viewable and hard-copy (print) output, the "variable-data publishing" term today often distinguishes output destined for electronic viewing, rather than that which is destined for hard-copy print (e.g. [[variable data printing]]).
Essentially the same techniques are employed to perform variable-data publishing, as those utilized with variable data printing. The difference is in the interpretation for output. While variable-data printing may be interpreted to produce various print streams or page-description files (e.g. [[Advanced Function Presentation|AFP]]/[[IPDS]], [[PostScript]], [[Printer Command Language|PCL]]), variable-data publishing produces electronically viewable files, most commonly seen in the forms of [[PDF]], [[HTML]], or [[XML]].
Variable-data composition involves the use of data to conditionally: * exhibit text (static blocks and/or variable content) * exhibit images * select fonts * select colors * format page layouts & flows
Variable-data may be as simple as an address block or salutation. However, it can be any or all of the document's textual content—including words, sentences, paragraphs, pages, or the entire document. In other words, it can make up as little or as much of the document as the composer desires. Variable data may also be used to exhibit various images, such as logos, products, or membership photos. Further, variable-data can be used to build rule-based design schemes, including fonts, colors, and page formats. The possibilities are vast.
The variable-data tools available today, make it possible to perform variable-data composition at nearly every stage of document production. However, the level of control that can be achieved varies, based upon how far into the document production process a variable-data tool is deployed. For example, if variable-data insertion occurs just prior to output...it's not likely that the text flow or layout can be altered with nearly as much control as would be available at the time of initial document composition.
Many organizations will produce multiple forms of output (aka: multi-channel output), for the same document. This ensures that the published content is available to recipients via any form of access method they might require. When multi-channel output is utilized, integrity between those output channels often becomes important.
Variable-data publishing may be performed on everything from a [[personal computer]] to a [[Mainframe computer|mainframe]] system. However, the speed and practical output volumes which can be achieved are directly affected by the computer power utilized.
==Origin of the concept==
The term variable-data publishing was likely an offshoot of the term "variable-data printing", first introduced to the printing industry by Frank Romano, Professor Emeritus, School of Print Media, at the [[College of Imaging Arts and Sciences]] at [[Rochester Institute of Technology]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}} However, the concept of merging static document elements and variable document elements predates the term and has seen various implementations ranging from simple desktop '[[mail merge]]', to complex [[Mainframe computer|mainframe]] applications in the financial and banking industry. In the past, the term VDP has been most closely associated with digital printing machines. However, in the past 3 years the application of this technology has spread to web pages, emails, and mobile messaging.
